terms of this article shall be subject to inspection by the president or a
village trustee or by the village chief of police or by any officer delegated
to such duty by the chief at any time the chief or officer may deem it
necessary and shall demand that the same be open for inspection. (1983 Code §
3-5-7)
4-3B-11: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this article shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (2011 Code)
ARTICLE C. SKATING RINKS
SECTION:
4-3C-1: License Required
4-3C-2: License Fee
4-3C-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to own, conduct or
operate any roller or ice skating rink within the village unless a license for
the same shall have been first obtained from the village clerk's office. (1983
Code § 3-13-1)
4-3C-2: LICENSE FEE:
The annual license fee for the operation of each roller or ice skating rink in
the village shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00), and said fee shall become
due and payable each year on May 1. (1983 Code § 3-13-2)
CHAPTER 4
RAFFLES
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: License And Compliance Required; Exemptions
4-4-3: Qualifications Of Licensee; Ineligibility For License
4-4-4: Application For License; Approval; No Fee
4-4-5: Duration Of License; Suspension Or Revocation
4-4-6: Conduct Of Raffles
4-4-7: Raffle Manager
4-4-8: Records And Reports
4-4-9: Penalty
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter and unless otherwise distinctly expressed, the
following words and phrases shall have the meanings set out herein:
NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable
sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating
expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT, CHARITABLE, EDUCATIONAL, RELIGIOUS, FRATERNAL, VETERANS, LABOR AND
POLITICAL COMMITTEE: Shall have the same meanings ascribed to them in 230
Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/2(b).
RAFFLE: A form of "lottery", as defined in section 28-2(b) of the criminal code
of 1961 1 , conducted by an organization licensed under this chapter, in which:
   A.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance.
   B.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery; except, that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
ROCK ISLAND COUNTY MODEL RAFFLE ORDINANCE: An ordinance in substantially the
same form, and containing the same provisions and limitations as is set forth
in this chapter to be enacted by any municipality located within Rock Island
County, Illinois, and intended to regulate the conduct of raffles within the
jurisdiction of the respective municipality. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000; amd. 2011
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 5/28-2(b).
4-4-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to conduct a
raffle within the village without having first obtained a license therefor
pursuant to this chapter or in violation of the terms of such license.
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation who has in his immediate possession a
valid license issued to the person, firm or corporation by another municipality
or political subdivision located in Rock Island County, Illinois, which
municipality or political subdivision has enacted the Rock Island County model
raffle ordinance (this chapter), shall be exempt from the requirements of this
section to have obtained a license from the village. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000)
4-4-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEE; INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable,
labor, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without
profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a
period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license
and which have had, during that entire five (5) year period, a bona fide
membership engaged in carrying out their objectives. Licenses shall be issued
to a nonprofit fundraising organization that the licensing authority determines
is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an
identified individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial
hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster. (Ord.
1196, 4-3-2000)
   B.   No such license shall be issued to:
      1.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony.
      2.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter.
      3.   Any person who is not of good moral character.
      4.   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection B1,
B2 or B3 of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest or in
which such a person is active or employed.
      5.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or
B3 of this section is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or
not.
      6.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or
B3 of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a
"raffle" as defined in section
4-4-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000; amd. 2011 Code)
4-4-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; APPROVAL; NO FEE:
   A.   Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk no
later than thirty (30) days prior to the commencement of sales or advertisement
of sale of raffle chances.
   B.   The application for license must specify the area or areas within the
village in which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of
determination of winning chances and the location or locations at which winning
chances will be determined.
   C.   The application for license must contain a sworn statement attesting to
the not for profit character of the prospective licensed organization and shall
be signed by the presiding officer and secretary of the organization.
   D.   The application for license must state the residence of the applicant
and all addresses of offices within the licensing municipality and, if the
raffle drawing is to be conducted within the licensing municipality, the
address of the location of the drawing.
   E.   Prior to approval, any application which indicates that the sale of
raffle chances would be in an area outside the corporate limits of the village,
or which indicates that the location or locations of determining winning
chances is or are outside the corporate limits of the village, shall be
referred to the licensing authority of such jurisdiction for comment as to
zoning status, licensed status of location, and compliance with licensing
regulations.
   F.   The village clerk shall act on a license application within thirty (30)
days from the date of application and shall notify all jurisdictions affected
thereby of said action.
   G.   No fee will be charged for the making of application and the issuance
of a raffle license. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000)
4-4-5: DURATION OF LICENSE; SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
A license authorizing the licensee to conduct "raffles", as defined in section
4-4-1 of this chapter, shall be valid for one raffle or for a specified number
of raffles to be conducted during a specified period not to exceed one year,
and may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter. (Ord. 1196,
4-3-2000)
4-4-6: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles licensed under this chapter is subject to the
following restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the raffle; however, this shall not prohibit the
payment of rent or a permit fee for use of facilities to hold a raffle if said
rent or fee is not dependent upon the raffle proceeds and is binding upon the
parties at the time made.
   D.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on
the license, and winning chances may be determined only at the locations
specified on the license.
   E.   A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances only with the permission of a parent or
guardian. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may be within the area
where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his parent
or guardian. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000)
4-4-7: RAFFLE MANAGER:
All operations of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of
a single raffle manager designated by the organization. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000)
4-4-8: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Records Kept:
      1.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deduction
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose,
amount, and date of payment.
      2.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license therefor, issued by the department of revenue of the state,
and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records
of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who
accounts for other revenues of the organization. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000)
   B.   Reports Required: Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall
report promptly after the conclusion of each raffle to its membership, and to
the village, its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles and
distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this chapter. (Ord. 1196,
4-3-2000; amd. 2011 Code)
4-4-9: PENALTY:
Violation of any provision of this chapter shall subject the person, firm, or
organization to a fine as provided in section
1-4B-1 of this code. (Ord. 1196, 4-3-2000; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 5
TRANSIENT MERCHANTS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: License Required; Exemptions
4-5-3: Application For License
4-5-4: Duplicate And Individual Licenses
4-5-5: Bond Requirements And Exemptions
4-5-6: Issuance Of License; Fees; Display
4-5-7: Denial And Revocation Of License; Appeal
4-5-8: Fixed Location Restrictions
4-5-9: Prohibited Activities
4-5-10: Penalty
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation of this chapter:
RESIDENCE: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes, by one
or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person, the nature of whose business activity indicates
the intent to remain in business in the village for less than one year, who:
   A.   Offers for sale tangible personal property or personal services; or
   B.   Takes or attempts to take orders for the sale of tangible personal
property or services, including advertising or subscriptions to be furnished or
performed in the future. (Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
4-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the
business of a transient merchant in the village without first obtaining a
license as provided in this chapter, except as provided in subsection B of this
section.
   B.   Exemptions: Persons engaged in the following described activities are
exempt from the duty of applying for a transient merchant license:
      1.   Persons selling at wholesale to merchants for the purpose of resale.
      2.   Persons selling or distributing newspapers.
      3.   Persons selling tangible personal property or services to business
enterprises.
      4.   Persons who sell, at their permanent residence in the village, works
of art or crafts made or created by such person or a member of such person's
immediate family.
      5.   Persons licensed by the state to sell real estate or insurance.
      6.   Persons selling or delivering tangible personal property or services
through a permanent business licensed by the village.
      7.   Events that are regulated by the village such as the annual Indian
Summer Festival and the M.I.P. events held on a semiannual basis. (Ord. 1176,
10-4-1999)
4-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for transient merchant license shall give the following
information:
   A.   The name or names of the person(s) having the management or supervision
of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed it will be carried
on in the village and the local address or addresses of such person(s) while
engaged in such business.
   B.   The permanent address or addresses of such person; whether such person
will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee and the credentials
establishing such relationship; the name and address of the person for whose
account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under
the laws of what state the same is incorporated.
   C.   The place or places in the village where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
said business shall be conducted.
   D.   The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant where the applicant, within three (3) years next preceding the date
of said application, conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof
and giving the post office box number and street address of any building or
office in which said business was conducted.
   E.   A statement of the nature and character of the tangible personal
property or service to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the
village; whether the goods are new, damaged or rejects; whether the same are
proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample; where the goods or
property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced; and where goods or
products are located at the time said application is filed.
   F.   Whether or not the person having management or supervision of the
applicant's business has been convicted of a felony within the five (5) years
immediately preceding the date of said application or of the violation of any
law or ordinance relating to the same or similar business to be conducted by
the applicant, the nature of such offense and the punishment therefor.
   G.   Whether the applicant has ever applied for a license under this chapter
which has been denied.
   H.   Whether the applicant has ever held a license under this chapter which
has been revoked. (Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
   I.   A signed statement from the applicant authorizing the village of Milan
to submit a criminal background check on said applicant to be conducted by the
Illinois state police, bureau of identification and the federal bureau of
investigation, together with payment of a background check fee to the village
of Milan, in the amount of seventy dollars ($70.00) per application. (Ord.
1568, 9-4-2012)
4-5-4: DUPLICATE AND INDIVIDUAL LICENSES:
A transient merchant license may be issued to a person carrying on the business
of transient merchant in the village through employees. Such employees shall
carry a duplicate license issued in the name of the employee identifying him or
her with the merchant, which license shall be obtained at the village clerk's
office. No bond will be required from the employee. (Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
4-5-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS AND EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Requirements:
      1.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, each applicant
for a transient merchant license or a blanket license hereunder shall file with
the village clerk a surety bond running to the village, in the penal sum set
forth herein, executed by the applicant as principal, and by a corporate surety
upon which service of process may be made in the state, the bond to be approved
by the village clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall comply with the
provisions of all of the ordinances of the village and the statutes of the
state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, subscriptions, wares,
merchandise or personal property of any nature, including foodstuffs, or for
services, including advertising, and will pay all judgments rendered against
the applicant for any violation of ordinances or statutes, or any of them,
together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against the
applicant by any person or persons for damage growing out of any
misrepresentation or deception practices on any person transacting such
business with the applicant, whether said misrepresentation or deception was
made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees,
either at the time of making the sale, or the solicitation of the sale, or
through any advertisements of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated
with reference to the subject matter of such sale or any part thereof. Action
on the bond may be brought in the name of the village to the use of the
aggrieved person. Such bond shall be further conditioned to indemnify and pay
the village for any penalties or costs occasioned by the enforcement of this
chapter and shall not be retired until after a lapse of one year from the
expiration of each license.
      2.   The penal sum of the bond required under the provisions of this
subsection is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or two (2) times the value of
the tangible personal property or service to be sold or offered for sale or the
average inventory to be carried by the transient merchant as shown by the
application, whichever amount is greater.
      3.   The applicant for a blanket license shall in all cases furnish a
bond described in subsection A2 of this section in the penal sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   B.   Exemptions:
      1.   The following persons shall be exempt from the requirement of
posting bond:
         a.   Persons selling or distributing on their property fresh fruit or
vegetables, plants, shrubs or flowers cultivated by such person.
         b.   Persons selling tangible personal property at a garage, basement
or yard sale held at one of the person's premises.
         c.   Persons who are receiving no compensation for their services for
selling tickets, chances or articles for religious, charitable, patriotic,
social service, civic or political nonprofit organizations.
         d.   Transient merchants selling subscriptions, tangible personal
property or services, where each sale does not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) to
any person and where, in addition, no payment, down payment or deposit
whatsoever is required to be made or paid until the property is actually
delivered or the services are actually performed.
      2.   Any person claiming an exemption under the provisions of this
subsection shall make request therefor in writing and shall state in said
request that the applicant shall not make any sales in violation of the
provisions of this subsection.
      3.   All licenses issued where the transient merchant is exempt from the
posting of bond under this section shall contain the following language: "No
bond has been furnished the village of Milan by the holder of this license".
(Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
4-5-6: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; FEES; DISPLAY:
   A.   If an application for a license under this chapter contains a complete
statement of the information required and all material required to be submitted
therewith is filed with the village clerk, the clerk shall issue the license
within twenty one (21) days, upon posting of the bond required by subsection
4-5-5A of this chapter and upon payment of the license fee. The license issued
hereunder shall not be transferable. There shall be no refund of the license
fee.
   B.   Before a license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay to the
village clerk a license fee according to the following schedule per person
engaged in sales as a transient merchant:
      1.   For door to door sales:
         a.   For one day, twenty five dollars ($25.00); for each additional
day, five dollars ($5.00).
         b.   For one month, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
         c.   For six (6) months, two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
         d.   For one year, four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00).
         e.   Duplicate license, five dollars ($5.00).
      2.   For roadside stands at a fixed location: For up to one year, twenty
five dollars ($25.00).
   C.   Each person engaged in sales as a transient merchant shall at all times
while doing business in the village keep in the possession of such person the
license required by this chapter and shall, upon request, display the license
as evidence of compliance with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 1470, 5-
5-2008)
4-5-7: DENIAL AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE; APPEAL:
   A.   Denial: The village clerk may deny a license to any applicant under
this chapter who has:
      1.   Held a license under this chapter that has been revoked within two
(2) years of the date of the present application.
      2.   Failed to make a complete application.
      3.   During the past two (2) years, a history of:
         a.   Fraudulent applications for similar licenses.
         b.   Misrepresentation of the quality of merchandise or services
offered for sale.
         c.   Crimes involving personal injury.
   B.   Revocation Of License: The village administrator may revoke any license
issued under the provisions of this chapter by sending a notice of revocation
by certified mail to the license holder at his last known address, return
receipt requested, or by personal service on the license holder or its officers
for any of the following causes:
      1.   Information showing that the license was erroneously issued
initially.
      2.   Any violation of the provisions of this chapter.
      3.   Any violation of any village or state law regulating the sales
activities of the license holder.
   C.   Appeal: The license shall stand denied or revoked unless, within five
(5) days after denial or receipt of the notice of revocation from the village
administrator, the applicant or holder files a written request for a public
hearing on the village administrator's action. A public hearing shall be
conducted before the village board of trustees on whether a license should be
denied, reinstated or revoked, as the case may be. The village board may order
the license issued or reinstated either conditionally or unconditionally, or
revoke the license. Ten (10) days' notice of the time and place of the public
hearing shall be given to the license holder, who shall have an opportunity to
appear before the village board and present any evidence or arguments he may
have why the action taken by the village administrator should not be approved
by the village board. (Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
4-5-8: FIXED LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   No transient merchant shall engage in business at a fixed location
without the written permission, by lease or otherwise, of the owner or person
in control of the property. This written agreement shall be signed by the
parties and shall include the dates the transient merchant shall be conducting
business. This agreement shall be displayed by the transient merchant at such
fixed location when he is doing business there.
   B.   A transient merchant doing business at a fixed location shall provide
sufficient off street parking space for his employees and customers.
   C.   Any display of tangible personal property, or signs or advertisements
therefor, shall be at least fifteen feet (15') from the curb line. All signs
and advertisements used in connection with the business licensed in this
chapter shall comply with the provisions of title 10, chapter 9 of this code.
   D.   The owner or person in control of the property shall furnish bathroom
facilities for the use of the transient merchant.
   E.   A transient merchant doing business at a fixed location shall do so
only in areas properly zoned for business activity. A transient merchant
selling food items shall comply with all applicable provisions of the health
rules and regulations of the county. (Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
4-5-9: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
   A.   No person shall engage in activities regulated under this chapter on
public property without first procuring special authorization from the village
board.
   B.   No person shall engage in business as a transient merchant in defiance
of any notice exhibited at a residence or business indicating that peddlers or
solicitors are not welcome or not invited.
   C.   No person shall engage in the activities regulated under this chapter
from door to door prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:
00) P.M. of any weekday or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national
holiday. (Ord. 1176, 10-4-1999)
4-5-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). Each sale or solicitation of a sale made without a license or bond
in violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1176,
10-4-1999; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 6
AUCTIONEERS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Definition
4-6-2: License Required
4-6-3: Application For License
4-6-4: Character Of Applicant
4-6-5: Bond Requirements
4-6-6: License Fees
4-6-7: Nontransferability Of License; Posting Required
4-6-8: Days And Hours Of Sale
4-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "auctioneer", as used in this chapter, includes any person, firm,
association, or corporation who or which shall engage in the conducting of
auction sales or crying off property at auction, except those who act by virtue
of legal process. The term "auctioneer" includes those who conduct an auction
sale or cry off their own property at auction, as well as those who conduct a
sale of or cry off the property of others. (1983 Code § 3-3-1)
4-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to exercise the
business or trade of an auctioneer, or sell or offer for sale by way of public
vendue, auction or outcry, within the village, any goods, wares, merchandise or
other effects whatsoever, without first having obtained a license and executed
a bond to the village as provided in this chapter. (1983 Code § 3-3-2)
4-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for an auctioneer's license shall state thereon the applicant's
business address, residence address, whether the license is for a single
auction or on an annual basis, time spent previously in the auctioneering
business and where, and the applicant's previous business name, if any. If the
application is for a license to conduct a single auction, the application shall
state the location where said auction shall be held and the time of holding
said auction. If the application is for a license to conduct auctions on an
annual basis, then the applicant, if licensed, shall report to the village
clerk's office at least fifteen (15) days prior to conducting any auction
during the license term, the place where each auction is to be held and the
time of conducting each auction. (1983 Code § 3-3-3)
4-6-4: CHARACTER OF APPLICANT:
All licenses shall be issued only to persons of good character. The village
chief of police shall investigate the character of each applicant before any
license shall be issued under the provisions hereof. (1983 Code § 3-3-5)
4-6-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall receive a license to sell goods at auction in the village until
he shall first have executed to the village a bond in the penal sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with corporate surety approved by the village
clerk, conditioned upon the strict observance of all ordinances of the village
respecting auctions and auctioneers and for the indemnification of any
purchaser at such public auction who suffers any loss by reason of
misrepresentation at such auction. The bond shall be kept in full force and
effect during the period for which the license is granted and shall, in
addition thereto, be kept in full force and effect for a period of thirty (30)
days after the expiration date of the license. (1983 Code § 3-3-4)
4-6-6: LICENSE FEES:
Any person may become an auctioneer and be licensed to sell personal or real
property at public auction in the village upon complying with the provisions of
this chapter and the payment of the license fee as follows:
   A.   For the right to conduct a single auction: Ten dollars ($10.00).
   B.   For the right to conduct auctions on an annual basis: Twenty five
dollars ($25.00). (1983 Code § 3-3-6)
4-6-7: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE; POSTING REQUIRED:
No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be transferable or
be held to authorize any person other than the one named therein to sell or cry
goods at auction. In no case shall any license be held to authorize any two (2)
persons to sell under it at one and the same time. The license shall in all
cases be posted in a conspicuous place where the sale is being held during the
time of such sale. (1983 Code § 3-3-7)
4-6-8: DAYS AND HOURS OF SALE:
No auctioneer shall sell or offer for sale on weekdays any goods, wares or
merchandise between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:
00) A.M., nor on Sundays; provided, that the president and board of trustees,
upon evidence that the peace and quiet of the neighborhood will not be
disturbed, may allow auction sales between the hours of five o'clock (5:00)
P.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on weekdays and between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on Sundays. (1983 Code § 3-3-
8)
CHAPTER 7
JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definitions
4-7-2: License Required
4-7-3: Application For License; Fee And Term
4-7-4: Ineligibility For License
4-7-5: Bond Requirements
4-7-6: Site Barriers
4-7-7: Prohibitions
4-7-8: Penalties
4-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
JUNK DEALER: Any person, firm or corporation which operates or maintains a junk
store or junkyard.
JUNKYARD OR JUNK STORE: Any business engaged in the purchase, trading in,
dealing in or storing of junk, rags, secondhand articles, motor vehicles
maintained for wrecking or for the ultimate purpose of selling, trading or
dealing in parts of said motor vehicles, and a business engaged in junking
motor vehicles. (1983 Code § 3-18-1)
4-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to locate, build,
construct, keep, operate or maintain any junk store or junkyard within the
village without first having obtained a license from the village. (1983 Code §
3-18-2)
4-7-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE AND TERM:
An application for a license to operate a junkyard or junk store shall state
the name of the person, firm or corporation making the application; the place
where said junkyard or junk store is to be located; a statement to the effect
that the proposed site for said junkyard or junk store does not conflict with
the provisions of section
4-7-4 of this chapter and shall be accompanied by a license fee of not less
than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), which license fee shall cover a
period of time of one year. The official licensing year shall begin on July 1
and end on June 30 of the next succeeding calendar year. All licenses shall
expire on said June 30 of each calendar year, but the license fee hereinabove
provided shall be reduced in proportion to the number of full calendar months
which have expired in the official license year prior to the issuance of such
license. (1983 Code § 3-18-3)
4-7-4: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
No license to operate or maintain a junkyard or junk store shall be issued by
the village under the following conditions:
   A.   If the proposed site of the junkyard or junk store is located within
three hundred feet (300') of any church, public or parochial school or grounds
thereof; and
   B.   If the owners of the property immediately adjacent to the proposed site
of the junkyard or junk store have failed to consent in writing to the proposed
site of said junkyard or junk store; and
   C.   If a majority of the owners of property located within a three hundred
foot (300') radius of the proposed site have not given their written consent to
the location of the proposed junkyard or junk store. (1983 Code § 3-18-4)
4-7-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Every person applying for a license to operate and maintain a junkyard or junk
store shall accompany such application with a bond in the penal sum of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with two (2) sufficient sureties thereon, which
bond shall be conditioned on the faithful observance by the licensee of the
ordinances of the village. Any person aggrieved by the acts of any licensee may
sue upon such bond and recover such damages therefrom as awarded by a court of
competent jurisdiction. (1983 Code § 3-18-5)
4-7-6: SITE BARRIERS:
A licensee under this chapter must erect a suitable site barrier not less than
six feet (6') in height to enclose all open junkyards or storage spaces. Said
site barrier shall be of a design and construction approved by the village
building inspector. The site barrier must be maintained in an approved
condition at all times. (1983 Code § 3-18-8)
4-7-7: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Purchases: No licensee shall buy, barter, or otherwise obtain any
article from any person known to the licensee to be intoxicated, a thief or a
minor unless a minor exhibits the written consent of a parent or guardian to
such dealer. (1983 Code § 3-18-6)
   B.   Placement Of Goods On Public Ways Or Private Property: No licensee
shall place or store any junk article or articles upon the sidewalks, parkways
or streets of the village or upon the property of another. (1983 Code § 3-18-7)
4-7-8: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-18-9; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 8
TAXICABS
SECTION:
4-8-1: Definition
4-8-2: License Required; Application
4-8-3: Character Of Applicant
4-8-4: License Fee And Vehicle Tags
4-8-5: Operators
4-8-6: Record Of Licensed Operators
4-8-7: Vehicle Requirements
4-8-8: Passengers
4-8-9: Rates Of Fare
4-8-10: Cab Stands
4-8-11: Unlawful Use Of Taxicabs
4-8-12: Penalties
4-8-1: DEFINITION:
The term "taxicab", as used in this chapter, shall mean and include any vehicle
used to carry passengers for hire but not operating on a fixed route. (1983
Code § 3-17-2)
4-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating a taxicab in the
village without first having secured a license therefor. Application for such
license shall be made in writing to the village clerk, and shall state thereon
the name of the applicant, the intended place of business and the number of
cabs to be operated. If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses
of the president and secretary thereof shall be given. (1983 Code § 3-17-1)
4-8-3: CHARACTER OF APPLICANT:
No license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of good
character or who has been convicted of a felony; nor shall such license be
issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof would be ineligible
for a license under the foregoing conditions. (1983 Code § 3-17-3)
4-8-4: LICENSE FEE AND VEHICLE TAGS:
   A.   The annual fee, payable in advance, for such licenses shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00) for each taxicab operated. Whenever the number of cabs so
operated shall be increased during the license year, the licensee shall notify
the village clerk of such change and shall pay the additional fee.
   B.   The village clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number
of cabs covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in a
prominent place on each taxicab while it is in use, and may be transferred to
any taxicab put into service to replace one withdrawn from service.
   C.   The licensee shall notify the village clerk of the motor vehicle number
and state license number of each cab operated and of the corresponding village
tag or number. (1983 Code § 3-17-4)
4-8-5: OPERATORS:
   A.   License Requirements:
      1.   License Required: No person shall drive a taxicab, or be hired or
permitted to do so, unless he is duly licensed as a chauffeur. (1983 Code § 3-
17-6)
      2.   Qualifications Of Licensee: No such license shall be issued to any
person who is not competent to operate a motor vehicle or who is not familiar
with the traffic laws and ordinances. The chief of police shall examine each
applicant for a taxicab driver's license to determine the competency of the
applicant, and no such license shall be issued excepting on certificate of the
chief that the applicant has demonstrated his ability to operate a motor
vehicle as required herein. (1983 Code § 3-17-15)
      3.   License Fee: The annual fee for a taxicab driver's license shall be
one dollar ($1.00). (1983 Code § 3-17-14)
      4.   Badge Requirements: Every person licensed as a driver under the
provisions of this chapter shall at all times, while acting as a driver of any
taxicab, wear a metal badge which shall have inscribed thereon "Milan,
Illinois, Taxicab Driver" and the year for which said license is issued. Such
badge shall be obtained from the chief of police, and the fee for such badge
shall be one dollar ($1.00). Such badge shall be provided with a pin or
fastener and shall be worn in a conspicuous place on the outside of the
driver's coat or upon his cap. It shall be unlawful to transfer any taxicab
driver's license or badge from one person to another. (1983 Code § 3-17-6)
      5.   Revocation Of License: The village president may revoke any taxicab
driver's license for repeated violations of traffic laws or of any ordinances
of the village. (1983 Code § 3-17-18)
   B.   Obedience To Traffic Laws: It shall be the duty of every driver of a
taxicab to obey all traffic rules established by statute or ordinance. (1983
Code § 3-17-8)
   C.   Prohibited Conduct: It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab
while on duty to drink any intoxicating liquor, or to use any profane or
obscene language, or to shout or call to prospective passengers, or to disturb
the peace in any way. (1983 Code § 3-17-6)
4-8-6: RECORD OF LICENSED OPERATORS:
The chief of police shall keep at his office a record in which shall be kept
the name and residence of each such licensed driver or operator and shall
carefully note opposite each such licensed driver's name such information as he
may gain concerning said licensed driver and as may be necessary to provide a
complete record of his conduct and qualifications as a driver or operator.
(1983 Code § 3-17-17)
4-8-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a state license duly
issued; and no such cab shall be operated unless it is equipped with proper
brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror, and windshield wiper
in good condition. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect every
taxicab so often as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the
provisions of this subsection. (1983 Code § 3-17-5)
   B.   No taxicab shall be operated unless it is covered by a bond or public
liability policy as required by statute. (1983 Code § 3-17-7)
   C.   Each taxicab, while being operated, shall have on each side, in letters
readable from a distance of twenty feet (20'), the name of the licensee
operating the taxicab. If more than one cab is operated by a licensee, each cab
shall be designated by a different number, and such number also shall so appear
on each side of such cab. (1983 Code § 3-17-5)
4-8-8: PASSENGERS:
It shall be the duty of the driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any
person who seeks to so use the taxicab, provided such person is not intoxicated
and conducts himself in an orderly manner. (1983 Code § 3-17-10)
4-8-9: RATES OF FARE:
   A.   The rates of fare which shall be asked or demanded by the operator or
persons in charge of taxicabs licensed hereunder and operated for convenience
of passengers for hire within the boundary or corporate limits of the village
shall be as follows:
From J. B. Young Housing to downtown only, senior special                 $1.50
To any point between 1st Avenue and Andalusia Road between the railroad   2.00
tracks and Route 67
To any point east of Route 67 and west of 8th Street East                 2.00
To Matthew Heights                                                        2.00
To Ginger Hill area, 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th and 13th Streets               2.00
To Windmill Farms                                                         2.00
To Suburban Heights                                                       2.25
To Hillcrest                                                              2.50
To the Oaks                                                               2.75
To Coyne Center                                                           3.25
To any point beyond 13th Street South and west on Andalusia Road          2.25
To Kenworth, 36th Street and 78th Avenue                                  3.00
To West Wind (Clover Hills)                                               3.00
To Paradise Manor, Knoxville Road                                         3.00
To Airview Trailer Court                                                  3.75
To Auto Acres                                                             3.00
To Moline Airport from downtown Milan ($0.50 airport charge will be added 5.00
to customer fare)
 
   B.   The fares provided in this section shall be deemed to be the maximum
charges that may be made by the operator or persons in charge of taxicabs
licensed under the provisions of this chapter. The fares herein provided shall
apply to each of the first two (2) passengers picked up at the same point to be
discharged at the same destination. Each additional passenger above the number
of two (2) picked up at the same point to be delivered at the same destination
shall be an additional fifty cents ($0.50) to the total fare that may be
charged. (1983 Code § 3-17-11)
4-8-10: CAB STANDS:
   A.   Any taxicab licensed under the provisions of this chapter may park at
such places as may from time to time be designated by the village board for
that purpose.
   B.   Each cab stand shall be appropriately marked by signs erected under the
supervision of the chief of police. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle,
other than a licensed taxicab, in any cab stand. (1983 Code § 3-17-12)
4-8-11: UNLAWFUL USE OF TAXICABS:
It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in the
perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor. (1983 Code § 3-17-9)
4-8-12: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-17-19; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 9
BICYCLE DEALERS
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definition
4-9-2: License Required
4-9-3: Application For License
4-9-4: No License Fee; Term Of License; Nontransferability
4-9-5: Registration Requirements
4-9-6: Penalty
4-9-1: DEFINITION:
The term "bicycle", for the purposes of this chapter, is any bicycle twenty
inches (20") or more in size. (Ord. 1145, 3-16-1998)
4-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to deal in the sale of three (3) or more bicycles within
any calendar year without a bicycle dealer's license. (Ord. 1145, 3-16-1998)
4-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The application for a license under the provisions of this chapter shall be
made in writing to the village clerk on a form provided by the village clerk's
office. (Ord. 1145, 3-16-1998)
4-9-4: NO LICENSE FEE; TERM OF LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABILITY:
There shall be no fee for a bicycle dealer's license, and the license shall
remain in effect from the date of issue until the business is closed, sold, or
ownership is transferred. Licenses are nontransferable. (Ord. 1145, 3-16-1998)
4-9-5: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be mandatory for all bicycle dealers dealing in the retail sale of
bicycles within the village to register all bicycles, size twenty inches (20")
or over, at the time of sale. The registration forms and bicycle license plates
shall be made available to the businesses at no cost through the Milan police
department. The completed registration forms shall be picked up twice a month
by a member of the police department. It shall be the responsibility of the
business owner and/or manager to notify the police department if he is in need
of additional registration forms and/or license plates. Persons registering a
bicycle at a bicycle dealer's place of business or at the police department
shall not be charged a fee. (Ord. 1145, 3-16-1998)
4-9-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall fined be as provided in section
1-4B-1 of this code. (Ord. 1145, 3-16-1998; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 10
BUILDING MOVERS
SECTION:
4-10-1: License Required
4-10-2: License Fee; Bond Requirements
4-10-3: Moving Fees
4-10-4: Permit To Move
4-10-5: Penalties
4-10-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall move any building or other structure along
the streets, avenues or alleys of the village unless he shall have first
obtained a license as a house mover. (1983 Code § 3-9-1)
4-10-2: LICENSE FEE; BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Any person, firm or corporation may obtain a license as a house mover upon the
payment of a license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per annum and
execution to the village of a bond in the sum of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) with at least two (2) good and sufficient sureties to be approved
by the village clerk, conditioned, among other things, that said party applying
for such license will pay the village, or the owner or owners, for any and all
damages which may occur to any trees, pavements, streets or sidewalks, or to
any telegraph, telephone, or electric light wire within the village, whether
said damage or injury shall be inflicted by said party or his agent, employees
or workers. The mover shall cut no wires, but shall give twenty four (24)
hours' notice to the owners of the same to remove and adjust them, and shall
pay the owner of the same their reasonable expense therefor, and conditioned
also that the party will save harmless and indemnify the village from all
liability, judgments, costs and expenses which may in any way accrue against
the village in consequence of the granting of such license or any permit, and
will in all things comply with the ordinances of the village and all permits
granted to the mover. (1983 Code § 3-9-2)
4-10-3: MOVING FEES:
Any person, firm or corporation licensed hereunder as a house mover shall, in
addition to all other fees provided herein, pay to the village clerk the sum of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each house to be moved in accordance with the
provisions herein and the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each garage,
shed or other small structure to be moved. (1983 Code § 3-9-3)
4-10-4: PERMIT TO MOVE:
The building inspector shall have authority to issue a permit to any of such
parties applying for same to occupy such portions of the streets so prayed for,
specifying in the permit all the privileges therein granted, with the terms and
conditions of the same, and the building inspector shall see that there is full
compliance therewith. (1983 Code § 3-9-4; amd. 2011 Code)
4-10-5: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-9-5; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 11
MOBILE HOME PARKS
SECTION:
4-11-1: Purpose
4-11-2: Definitions
4-11-3: License To Operate And Permit To Construct Required
4-11-4: Applications For License And Permit
4-11-5: Issuance Or Denial Of License And Permit
4-11-6: License Fee
4-11-7: Transfer Of License
4-11-8: Posting License And Permit
4-11-9: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
4-11-10: Construction And Operation Requirements
4-11-11: Office And Registry
4-11-12: Report To School Boards
4-11-13: Records Kept; Information Provided
4-11-14: Inspections
4-11-15: Penalty
4-11-1: PURPOSE:
For the purpose of promoting the public health, safety, morals, comfort and
general welfare; providing for adequate water, sanitary sewage facilities, and
other necessary facilities for the comfort and convenience of persons occupying
mobile homes in the village, this chapter is established. (1983 Code §
5-6-1)
4-11-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and phrases set forth
in this section and as used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed as
follows:
DEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A mobile home which does not have toilet and bath or
shower facilities. Such a mobile home shall not be allowed in a mobile home
park in the village of Milan.
INDEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A mobile home which has self- contained toilet and
bath or shower facilities.
MOBILE HOME: A structure designed for permanent habitation and so constructed
as to permit its transport on wheels, temporarily or permanently attached to
its frame, from the place of its construction to the location, or subsequent
locations, at which it is intended to be a permanent habitation and designed to
permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling place for one or more persons;
provided, that any such structure resting on a permanent foundation, with
wheels, tongue and hitch permanently removed, shall not be construed a "mobile
home".
MOBILE HOME PARK: An area of land or lands upon which five (5) or more
independent mobile homes are available for permanent habitation either free of
charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure,
tent, vehicle, or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment
of such "mobile home park".
PERMANENT HABITATION: A period of two (2) or more months.
SITE: The lot on which the mobile home is located for permanent habitation.
(1983 Code §
5-6-2; amd. 2011 Code)
4-11-3: LICENSE TO OPERATE AND PERMIT TO CONSTRUCT REQUIRED:
   A.   License: No person, firm, or corporation shall establish, maintain,
conduct, or operate a mobile home park after April 30, 1954, without first
obtaining a license therefor from the village clerk. Such license shall be
issued for one year and shall expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on
April 30 of the year next following the issuance thereof, and the license shall
be renewed from year to year upon payment of the annual license fee herein
provided. (1983 Code §
5-6-3)
   B.   Permit: No person, firm or corporation shall construct a mobile home
without first obtaining a permit to do so. (1983 Code §
5-6-8)
4-11-4: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSE AND PERMIT:
   A.   In order to obtain a permit to construct or an original license to
operate a mobile home park, the applicant shall file with the village clerk a
written application setting forth:
      1.   The full name and address of the applicant or applicants, or names
and addresses of the partners if the applicant is a partnership, or the names
and addresses of the officers if the applicant is a corporation, and the
present or last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the
application.
      2.   Address, location and legal description of the tract of land,
certified on a plat of survey by an Illinois registered land surveyor, drawn to
scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100'), or larger.
      3.   The proposed and existing facilities of the mobile home park for
water supply, sewage, garbage and waste disposal, and fire protection, and for
a sanitary community building which will include a description of toilets,
urinals, sinks, washbasins, slop sinks, showers, drains and laundry facilities,
the proposed alterations therein and the maintenance thereof.
      4.   The proposed method of lighting the structures and the land upon
which the mobile home park is to be located.
      5.   The plot plans of the mobile home park, building plans, and
specifications for existing buildings and facilities, and the plans and
specifications for new buildings and facilities or the proposed alterations in
existing facilities, all as may be required by the rules and regulations of the
village clerk under the provisions of this chapter.
      6.   Each street or driveway within the park shall be assigned a name or
number, and each mobile home shall be identified by number, such number being
clearly visible from the street or driveway. All names or numbers identifying
streets, driveways, and mobile home sites shall be shown on plat plans. All
street numbering shall be in conformance with the village street number system.
      7.   A statement of the firefighting facilities, public or private, which
are available to the mobile home park.
      8.   Name of mobile home park.
      9.   Number of mobile home sites proposed to be constructed. (1983 Code §
5-6-4; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   An affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the matters contained
in the application shall be attached thereto. Each application shall be
accompanied by an application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus a three
dollar ($3.00) inspection service charge for each mobile home space located in
the mobile home park as provided in section
4-11-6 of this chapter. The application fee, once paid to the village clerk,
shall not be refunded.
   C.   Permits shall be valid for one year from date of issue but may be
extended by the village board of trustees. (1983 Code §
5-6-4)
4-11-5: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE AND PERMIT:
   A.   Issuance Of Permit: Upon receipt of an application for a permit to
construct a mobile home park, the village clerk shall submit said application
to the village planning commission at the next duly called meeting thereof. If
the planning commission, by majority vote, approves said application and if the
park is, or the proposed park will be, in conformity with this chapter and the
rules and regulations adopted by the village board of trustees pursuant thereto
and all applicable state statutes, the village clerk shall issue a permit to
construct said mobile home park.
   B.   Issuance Of License: Upon receipt of an application for a license to
operate and maintain a mobile home park, the village clerk shall, if the park
is in conformity with this chapter and the rules and regulations adopted by the
village board of trustees pursuant thereto and all applicable state statutes,
issue a license to operate and maintain the same.
   C.   Denial Of License Or Permit: If the application for a permit to
construct or a license is declined, the village clerk shall give the reasons
therefor, in writing, to the applicant; and if the objections can be corrected,
the applicant may amend his application and resubmit it for approval. (1983
Code §
5-6-7)
   D.   Conditions Of Issuance:
      1.   If a permit to construct a mobile home park has been issued, the
applicant, upon completion of construction, shall notify the village clerk. The
license committee shall then inspect the mobile home park, and if completed in
accordance with the accepted application, the village clerk shall issue a
license. (1983 Code §
5-6-7; amd. 2011 Code)
      2.   Upon receipt of permit to construct, the applicant shall begin
construction of the mobile home park within one year of the date of the permit
to construct.
      3.   No change in any sanitary facilities, methods of water supply,
sewer, drainage, or garbage or waste disposal, and no change in the plot plan
shall be made without first making a written application to the village clerk
and receiving a written permit therefrom. Such application shall be made in the
way and manner hereinbefore set forth; except, that a fee amounting to fifty
dollars ($50.00) shall accompany each application for a permit to increase the
size of a park. No application fee shall be required to accompany an
application for a permit to alter a mobile home park where such alteration
involves only a reduction in the number of mobile home spaces to a number less
than that for which such park is currently licensed. (1983 Code §
5-6-7)
4-11-6: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Established; Prorated Fee: In addition to the application fee provided
in subsection
4-11-4B of this chapter, the licensee shall pay to the village clerk on or
before April 30 of each year, an annual license fee which shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00); provided, that subsequent to the effective date hereof, an
applicant for an original license to operate a new park constructed under a
permit issued by the village clerk shall only be required to pay one-fourth (1/
4) of the annual fee if such park begins operation after January 31 and before
May 1 of such licensing year; or one-half (1/2) of the annual fee if such park
begins operation after October 31 and before February 1 of such licensing year;
or three-fourths (3/4) of the annual fee if such park begins operation after
July 31 and before November 1 of such licensing year; but shall be required to
pay the entire annual fee if such park begins operation after April 30 and
before August 1 of such licensing year. This subsection is applicable as long
as the village uses April 30 as an annual license date.
   B.   Payment Of Fee; No Refunds: Each license fee shall be paid to the
village clerk, and any license fee or any part thereof, once paid to and
accepted by the village clerk, shall not be refunded. (1983 Code §
5-6-6)
4-11-7: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued under this chapter shall be nontransferable without the
written consent of the licenser; provided, however, that the licenser may not
withhold such consent where the provisions of the chapter have been met. (1983
Code §
5-6-8)
4-11-8: POSTING LICENSE AND PERMIT:
All permits to construct and all licenses to operate and all permits to make
alterations therein shall be prominently displayed in the office of mobile home
park. (1983 Code §
5-6-8)
4-11-9: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license granted hereunder shall be subject to revocation or suspension by
the village board of trustees. However, the village clerk shall first serve or
cause to be served upon the licensee a written notice in which shall be
specified the way or ways in which such licensee has failed to comply with this
chapter. Said notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate any nuisance
or unsanitary or objectionable condition specified in the notice within five
(5) days or within a longer period of time as may be allowed by the village
board of trustees. If the licensee fails to comply with the terms and
conditions of said notice within the time specified or such extended period of
time, the village board of trustees may revoke or suspend the license. (1983
Code §
5-6-7)
4-11-10: CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION REQUIREMENTS:
Each mobile home park licensed or to be constructed under the provisions of
this chapter shall provide for the following and in the following manner:
   A.   Supervision: Every mobile home park shall have a responsible attendant
or caretaker in charge at all times, whose duty it shall be to maintain the
park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition,
and be answerable, with the licensee, for any violation of the provisions of
this chapter.
   B.   Location And Space:
      1.   No mobile home park shall be so located that the drainage of the
park area will endanger any water supply. All such parks shall be well drained
and shall be located in areas free from ponds, swamps, and similar places in
which mosquitoes may breed. No wastewater from mobile homes shall be deposited
on the surface of the ground.
      2.   Each mobile home shall be allotted a site of not less than four
thousand (4,000) square feet. No mobile home shall be parked closer than
fifteen feet (15') to the side lot lines of a mobile home park, or closer than
fifteen feet (15') to a street right of way or building. Each individual mobile
home site shall abut or face on a paved driveway or street of not less than
twenty five feet (25') in width for two-way streets and not less than eighteen
feet (18') in width for one-way streets, and situated within a public right of
way of not less than twenty seven feet (27') in width for a two-way street and
not less than twenty feet (20') for a one-way street, which driveway or street
shall have unobstructed access to a public street or highway. There shall be an
open space of at least fifteen feet (15') adjacent to the sides of every mobile
home lot and at least eleven feet (11') adjacent to the rear lot line of every
mobile home site.
   C.   Water Supply: Each mobile home shall be individually connected to the
public water supply for the village in an approved manner.
   D.   Sewage Disposal:
      1.   All sewage and other water carried wastes shall be disposed of into
the village sewerage system in an approved manner.
      2.   It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of the park to provide
an approved type of watertight and odortight connection from the mobile home
water drainage to the sewer connection, and it shall be the duty of the owner
or operator to make such connection and keep all occupied mobile homes
connected to the sewer while located in the park. Sewer connections in
unoccupied sites shall be so closed that they will emit no odors or cause a
breeding place for flies. No water or waste shall be allowed to fall on the
ground from a mobile home.
   E.   Garbage Disposal:
      1.   A sufficient number of adequate flyproof and watertight containers
shall be supplied for the storage of garbage except where an adequate
incinerator is provided.
      2.   Garbage containers shall be emptied at least once a week and shall
not be filled to overflowing or allowed to become foul smelling or a breeding
place for flies.
      3.   Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates
neither a nuisance nor a menace to health and which is approved by the village.
   F.   Pest Control: Adequate insect and rodent control measures shall be
employed. All buildings shall be flyproof and rodentproof, and rodent
harborages shall not be permitted to exist in the park or pathways.
   G.   Fire Extinguishers: Mobile homes in mobile home parks shall each be
equipped with fire extinguishers in working order, one in each end of the
mobile home. Inspection of any such equipment and enforcement of any rules and
regulations adopted pursuant to this subsection shall be the duty of the state
fire marshal and the village police department.
   H.   Electrical Outlets: Electrical outlets for each individual site shall
be provided, and the installation shall be in accordance with all state or
local codes and ordinances.
   I.   Temporary Porches, Canopies And Skirting: Temporary porches, canvas
roofed canopies and skirts shall be permitted for mobile homes, and auxiliary
rooms may also be authorized by the village board of trustees if constructed of
fire resistant materials of such specifications as shall be required by such
regulations.
   J.   Streets And Driveways: All streets and driveways in every park shall
conform to the village subdivision regulations, and all streets and driveways
in every park established after January 1, 1954, and prior to October 18, 1971,
shall have a minimum width of twenty feet (20'); all streets and driveways in
every park established after October 18, 1971, shall have a minimum dedicated
width of fifty feet (50') and a minimum paved width of twenty five feet (25')
as hereinbefore provided. (1983 Code §
5-6-9)
   K.   Compliance With Building Regulations: All buildings constructed or
altered, all plumbing, and all electrical and heating installations shall be in
accordance with existing village building regulations, except as otherwise
approved on the applicant's plans by the village clerk and after such
exceptions have been approved by action of the village board of trustees. (1983
Code § 5-6-11)
   L.   Maintenance And Repair:
      1.   The management of every park shall assume full responsibility for
maintaining in good repair and condition all sanitary, electrical and safety
appliances in the park, and shall promptly bring such action as is necessary to
prosecute or eject from the park any person or persons who wilfully or
maliciously damage such appliances, or any person or persons who fail to comply
with the regulations of this chapter. (1983 Code §
5-6-9)
      2.   When community kitchens, dining rooms, laundries, or other
facilities are provided, such facilities and equipment as are supplied must be
maintained in a sanitary condition and kept in good repair, and subject to the
building code adopted by the village. (1983 Code § 5-6-10; amd. 2011 Code)
   M.   Other Structures And Vehicles Prohibited: In no event shall a dependent
mobile home or nonpermanent shelter or other vehicle designed or used for
sleeping purposes, other than an independent mobile home, be permitted for
occupancy at any time in a mobile home park. (1983 Code §
5-6-9)
4-11-11: OFFICE AND REGISTRY:
Each mobile home park shall be provided with a custodian's office where each
mobile home entering such park shall be assigned to a site, given a copy of the
park rules and registered according to the prescribed form. Such registration
shall include the name and address of the owner and every occupant of such
mobile home. Such registration shall also include the license number of such
mobile home and of the towing vehicle, if there be any, and the state issuing
the licenses. The register shall be signed by the owner or operator of the
mobile home. Any person furnishing misinformation for purposes of registration
shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall, upon
conviction thereof, be subject to a fine hereinafter provided. The registration
records shall be neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records
shall be destroyed until six (6) years have elapsed following the date of
registration. The register shall be available at all times for inspection by
all law enforcement officers and by the village clerk. (1983 Code § 5-6-14)
4-11-12: REPORT TO SCHOOL BOARDS:
It shall be the duty of each licensee, on February 1 and September 1 of each
year, to file with the school board or boards of the school district or
districts wherein the mobile home park is located, a report giving the names
and ages of all children of school age living in said mobile home park. (1983
Code § 5-6-15)
4-11-13: RECORDS KEPT; INFORMATION PROVIDED:
   A.   Permits And Licenses:
      1.   When the village board has approved an application for a permit to
construct or make alterations upon a mobile home park or the appurtenances
thereto or a license to operate and maintain the same, the village clerk shall
retain the original and keep a file thereof, and one copy shall be returned to
the applicant or his agent.
      2.   The village clerk shall draft and supply all forms and blanks and
specify the number and detail necessary to obtain permits to construct or make
alterations upon parks and for a license to operate and maintain such a park
according to this chapter. (1983 Code § 5-6-12)
   B.   Mobile Home Parks: The village clerk shall keep a record of all mobile
home parks; said records to show the names and addresses of the licensees,
number of mobile home lots in each park, source of water supply, system of
sewage and garbage disposal, and any other information desired by the village
board of trustees.
   C.   Health Rules And Regulations: The village clerk shall supply licensees
of all parks with any and all health rules and regulations pertaining thereto
made by the village and any change or changes that may be made from time to
time, and such rules and regulations shall be posted by the management of the
park in a protected, conspicuous place within the park. (1983 Code § 5-6-13)
4-11-14: INSPECTIONS:
The licensing committee may inspect from time to time each mobile home park
licensed under the provisions of this chapter to determine whether or not the
licensee and the mobile home park are complying with the terms of this chapter.
(1983 Code § 5-6-16)
4-11-15: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation convicted of a violation of this chapter shall
be fined as provided in section
1-4B-1 of this code. Each day of violation shall be a separate offense. (1983
Code § 5-6-17; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 12
TATTOO AND/OR BODY PIERCING ESTABLISHMENTS AND ARTISTS
SECTION:
4-12-1: Statute Authority
4-12-2: Purpose; No Guarantee Or Warranty
4-12-3: Definitions
4-12-4: Licenses Required; Fees
4-12-5: Applications For Licenses
4-12-6: Display Of Licenses
4-12-7: Artist Restrictions And Requirements Generally
4-12-8: Tattooing And Piercing Procedures
4-12-9: Physical Facilities
4-12-10: Equipment
4-12-11: Sterilization Procedure
4-12-12: Days And Hours Of Operation
4-12-13: Existing Establishments
4-12-14: Inspections
4-12-15: Revocation Of License
4-12-16: Exemptions From Provisions
4-12-17: Conflicting Provisions
4-12-18: Penalty
4-12-1: STATUTE AUTHORITY:
The provisions of this chapter are adopted pursuant to authority granted by 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-5 and 5/11-60-2. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-2: PURPOSE; NO GUARANTEE OR WARRANTY:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public interest by reducing the
dangers involved in unregulated practice of tattooing and/or body piercing.
Neither the issuance of a license, the making of an inspection without finding
violations, or any other act by the village shall constitute a guarantee or
warranty that any equipment or any treatment is safe or effective, or that any
tattooing and/or body piercing establishment will perform without making
errors. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ASEPTIC TECHNIQUE: A practice that prevents and hinders the transmission of
disease producing micro-organisms from one person or place to another person or
place.
BODY PIERCING: The piercing of the surface of the skin anywhere on a human body
with the aid of needles or other devices for the purpose of attaching rings or
adornments of any kind.
CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION: Written approval signed by the Milan building
inspector, village administrator and chief of police, or any two (2) of them,
after receipt of the recommendation of the Rock Island County health
department, that a tattooing and/or body piercing establishment has been
inspected and meets all of the terms of this chapter relating to physical
facilities, equipment and layout for operation of such business. Said writing
shall be on a form designated by the village of Milan for such purpose.
FACIAL TATTOO OR FACIAL PIERCING: Any tattooing or piercing applied above the
jawline, including the eyelids, eyebrows, ears, nose, or lips.
OPERATOR: Any individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation or
association that owns or operates an establishment where tattooing and/or body
piercing is performed.
SANITIZE: To treat a clean surface and destroy pathogenic micro-organisms.
SINGLE SERVICE ITEMS: Articles intended for onetime, one person use and are to
be discarded after use.
TATTOO AND/OR BODY PIERCING ARTIST: Any individual who performs or practices
the art of tattooing or body piercing on the person of another.
TATTOO, TATTOOED, TATTOOING: An indelible mark or decorative design created by
the introduction of dyes or pigments beneath the surface of the skin with the
aid of needles or other devices. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000; amd. Ord. 1230, 2-19-
2001)
4-12-4: LICENSES REQUIRED; FEES:
   A.   Business: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business
of operating a tattooing and/or body piercing establishment within the village
without first paying an annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00),
payable to the village clerk's office after having first received a certificate
of inspection in proper form in accordance with the provisions hereof.
   B.   Artist: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any tattooing
and/or body piercing without a license, issued pursuant to the provisions of
this chapter, or to employ any person as a tattooer or body piercer who has not
paid an annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each artist to the
village clerk's office in accordance with the provisions hereof. (Ord. 1192, 3-
6-2000)
4-12-5: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
Any person desiring to obtain or renew a license to operate a tattooing and/or
body piercing establishment or a tattoo artist's and/or body piercing artist's
license shall make application to the village clerk who shall refer all such
applications to the building inspector, village administrator and chief of
police. The application for a tattooing and/or body piercing license required
by this chapter shall contain the following information:
   A.   Full name and current address.
   B.   The two (2) previous addresses of the applicant immediately prior to
the current address.
   C.   Written proof that the applicant is over the age of eighteen (18)
years.
   D.   Applicant's height, weight and color of eyes and hair.
   E.   The tattooing and/or body piercing license history of the applicant,
including whether such person in previous operation in this or another area has
had his license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and any business
activity or occupation subsequent to the action of suspension or revocation.
   F.   A certificate of a medical doctor designating that the applicant has
recently been examined and is free of any contagious or communicable disease
which, in the opinion of the medical doctor, can be transmitted during the
tattooing process. Immunization for hepatitis B is strongly recommended. (Ord.
1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSES:
Every person to whom a license shall have been granted under the provisions of
this chapter shall display said license in a conspicuous place. Failure to
display said license shall be grounds for revocation. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-7: ARTIST RESTRICTIONS AND REQUIREMENTS GENERALLY:
   A.   No tattoo and/or body piercing artist shall practice tattooing and/or
body piercing in any place other than a tattoo or body piercing parlor having a
valid license.
   B.   No tattoo and/or body piercing artist shall apply a tattoo and/or body
piercing to any person who appears to be or admits to being under the influence
of intoxicating substances, including, but not limited to, alcohol, drugs,
paints or glues.
   C.   No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo in violation of section 12-10 of
the criminal code of 1961.
   D.   Immediately after tattooing and/or body piercing, the artist shall
advise the client, in writing, on the care of the tattoo and/or body pierce,
and instruct the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection.
(Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-8: TATTOOING AND PIERCING PROCEDURES:
   A.   Hygiene: All tattoo and/or body piercing artists shall comply with the
following:
      1.   No employee, while infected with a disease in a communicable form,
or who is a carrier of a disease which can be transmitted during the tattooing
and/or body piercing process, and no employee while infected with a boil,
infected wound or acute respiratory infection shall provide tattooing and/or
body piercing to a client.
      2.   No employee shall provide tattooing and/or body piercing to any skin
surface that shows evidence of any rash, boils, infections or other unhealthy
conditions or diseases.
      3.   Employees shall thoroughly wash their hands and exposed portions of
their arms with soap and warm water before starting work, during work as often
as is necessary to keep them clean, and after smoking, eating, drinking and
using the toilet. Employees shall keep their fingernails clean and trimmed.
      4.   Employees providing tattooing and/or body piercing shall, in
addition to thoroughly washing, use single use latex or vinyl examination
gloves as a barrier to potentially infective blood.
      5.   Employees shall not use tobacco in any form, or eat or drink while
tattooing a client.
   B.   Tattooing And Body Piercing Generally:
      1.   The tattooing and/or body piercing artist shall explain in writing
the following to each client before a tattoo and/or body pierce application and
obtain an informed consent signed by the client and maintain such consent for
at least five (5) years:
         a.   The application procedure.
         b.   Possible tissue reactions, infections and dye reactions following
application.
         c.   Importance of after application care.
      2.   The area of skin to be worked on shall first be thoroughly washed
and scrubbed for a period of two (2) minutes with warm water to which has been
added an antiseptic liquid soap. A sterile single use sponge shall be used to
scrub the area. After shaving and before the tattooing and/or body piercing is
begun, a solution of seventy percent (70%) alcohol or other effective
germicidal solution shall be applied to the area with a single use sponge used
and applied with a sterile instrument.
      3.   For tattooing and/or body piercing, single service or individual
containers of dye or ink shall be used for each patron, and the container
therefor shall be discarded immediately after completing work on a patron; any
dye in which the needles were dipped shall not be used on another person.
      4.   Whenever a new sterile tube is used that contains a different color
of dye or ink, a separate or new sterile needle shall also be used. Excess dye
or ink shall be removed from the skin with an individual single use sterile
sponge or disposable paper tissue which shall be used only on one person and
then immediately discarded. After completing work on any person, the tattooed
and/or body pierced area shall be washed with sterile gauze saturated with an
antiseptic soap solution, or a seventy percent (70%) alcohol solution. The
tattooed area shall be allowed to dry, and petroleum jelly from a collapsible
or plastic tube shall be applied, using sterile gauze. A sterile gauze dressing
shall then be fastened to the tattooed and/or body pierced area with adhesive.
      5.   Only clean single service stencils may be used.
      6.   Only sterilized needles and tubes or tips, in good condition, shall
be used for tattooing and/or body piercing.
      7.   Persons tattooed and/or body pierced shall be provided with printed
