instructions regarding tattoo and/or body pierce care during the healing
process and shall be instructed to consult a physician if signs and symptoms of
an infection develop.
      8.   Single use needles, razors or other sharp materials must be disposed
of immediately upon completion of tattooing and/or body piercing within EPA and
OSHA approved sharps disposal containers.
      9.   Used tattoo and/or body piercing needles and other infectious waste
shall be stored, treated, and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of
title XV of the environmental protection act which regulates the management and
disposal of infectious waste 1 .
   C.   Facial Tattoos And Piercings:
      1.   Application of facial tattoos and/or body piercing is prohibited
except by a physician or by a tattoo and/or body piercing artist performing
facial tattoos and/or piercings under the general supervision of a physician.
"General supervision" shall include the examination of the person receiving the
tattoo and/or body piercing by the supervising physician before and after
application of the tattoo and/or body pierce. The physician shall check for any
signs of medical complications, including infection or allergic reactions.
Appropriate documentation of the examination by the physician shall be kept on
file at the tattoo and/or body piercing parlor on a form prescribed by the
village.
      2.   All tattoo and/or body piercing artists who apply facial tattoos
and/or facial piercings shall provide to the village a written statement from
the tattoo and/or body piercing artist's supervising physician verifying their
working relationship on a form prescribed by the village. The written
verification shall be submitted to the village before any change of the
supervising physician and at each annual renewal of the tattoo and/or body
piercing artist's license. Failure to provide written verification shall be
grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of the artist's license.
      3.   The use of injections is prohibited unless administered by a
physician or by a registered nurse licensed under the Illinois nursing act of
1987 and acting under the direction of a duly licensed physician.
      4.   Facial tattoo and/or facial piercing artists may apply topical
anesthetics with the approval of a supervising physician. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/56 et seq.
4-12-9: PHYSICAL FACILITIES:
All tattooing and/or body piercing parlors shall comply with the following
requirements in order to qualify for a license:
   A.   The tattooing and/or body piercing room and waiting areas shall be
separated by a solid partition or barrier that prevents unauthorized entry into
the tattooing and/or body piercing room and provides privacy for clients.
   B.   All floors, walls, ceilings, and procedure surfaces shall be
constructed from materials that are easily cleanable, smooth, nonabsorbent,
durable, light colored, and in good repair. The tattooing and/or body piercing
establishment shall be maintained in a sanitary condition.
   C.   A separate, readily accessible hand sink with hot and cold running
water shall be provided at each workstation for the exclusive use of the artist
for hand washing and preparing the client for tattooing and/or body piercing.
The hand sink shall be under pressure with a mixing valve or combination
faucet. Soap, an approved hand drying device such as disposable paper towels,
and a refuse container with a cover shall be provided at each hand sink.
   D.   All tattooing and/or body piercing establishments shall be provided
with at least one utility sink or curbed cleaning facility with a floor drain
for the cleaning of mops or similar wet floor cleaning equipment and for the
disposal of mop water or similar liquid waste.
   E.   Adequate lighting and ventilation shall be provided within the
establishment.
   F.   No animals of any kind shall be allowed in an establishment except for
canines accompanying the visually disabled.
   G.   Effective measures shall be taken by the operator to prevent and
maintain the establishment free of pest and/or rodent infestations.
   H.   An adequate number of lockers or other suitable facilities shall be
provided and used for orderly storage of employee clothing and other
belongings.
   I.   Smoking and the use of tobacco in any form shall be prohibited in the
tattooing and/or body piercing room.
   J.   Any other business or dwelling shall be completely separated from the
tattooing and/or body piercing parlor by at least a solid partition from the
floor to the ceiling. Only tattooing and/or body piercing shall be permitted in
the parlor. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-10: EQUIPMENT:
   A.   All service table surfaces shall be constructed of nonporous, easily
cleanable material, and sanitized after each client.
   B.   All inks, dyes, needles and equipment shall be specifically
manufactured for performing body art procedures and shall be used according to
the manufacturer's instructions. All dyes or pigments used in tattooing shall
be nontoxic, free from adulteration and made from materials generally regarded
as safe.
   C.   Sterile single service or sterile individual containers of dye or ink
shall be used for each patron. Ink cups shall be for single patron use with the
ink cup holder constructed from material that is easily cleanable.
   D.   All tubes, needle bars and instruments used in the tattooing and/or
body piercing procedures that are not sterile single patron use and disposable
shall be thoroughly cleaned and steam sterilized or dry heat sterilized between
patrons. After sterilization, equipment used in the tattooing and/or body
piercing procedure shall be stored in a dry, clean cabinet or other tightly
covered container reserved for the storage of such instruments. Each tattoo
artist will be provided with a storage cabinet for the exclusive storage of
instruments, dyes, pigments, carbon, stencils, and other paraphernalia used in
the parlor.
   E.   Needles shall be disposable, sterile, single patron use or shall be
reusable needles and shall be thoroughly cleaned and steam sterilized or dry
heat sterilized between patrons. Needles, tubes, and tips shall be constructed
in a manner that permits easy cleaning and sterilization. Needles and
assemblies designed to be disposable shall be used one time, on one person
only, and then discarded in accordance with subsections
4-12-8B8 and B9 of this chapter.
   F.   Razors shall be single patron use and disposable, or shall have the
handle of the razor sterilized with a new blade used for each patron. Alum or
other material used to stop the flow of blood shall be used only in a liquid or
powder form.
   G.   Topical ointment or medication shall be packaged for single patron use.
All bandages and dressings shall be sterile and single use.
   H.   All instruments used for tattooing and/or body piercing shall remain
stored in sterile packages until just prior to the performance of the tattoo
and/or body piercing procedures. The artist shall wear disposable medical
gloves and use medically recognized techniques to ensure that the instruments
and gloves are not contaminated. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-11: STERILIZATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Each tattooing and/or body piercing parlor engaged in the practice of
tattooing and/or body piercing shall utilize sterilization equipment adequate
in size to accommodate needles, tubes, tips and other related utensils and
equipment, and only sterilization equipment with the capacity to make a
permanent record of the temperatures and pressures in the machines may be used.
All records shall be permanently retained by the licensee and made available
for inspection by the village on demand.
   B.   After each use, the needles and assemblies shall be cleansed to remove
protein residue (blood and tissue) and sterilized.
   C.   One of the following methods of sterilization shall be used:
      1.   Autoclave - steam under pressure: One hundred twenty one degrees
Celsius (121°C) (250°F) at greater than ten (10) psi for not less than thirty
(30) minutes after the chamber of the autoclave has been evacuated of air and
has reached temperature; or as specified in the manufacturer's operator's
manual.
      2.   Dry heat sterilization: One hundred seventy degrees Celsius (170°C)
(338°F) for not less than two (2) hours after the sterilizer has reached
temperature; or as specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual.
      3.   Other methods approved by the village.
   D.   Sterilization shall be monitored by the use of chemical and heat
sensitive (color change) indicators with each batch of equipment sterilized or
by other methods approved by the village.
   E.   Sterilized equipment shall be stored wrapped or covered in a manner
that ensures the equipment will remain sterile until used. Each batch shall be
labeled with the date of sterilization. If exposed to any potential source of
contamination, the equipment shall be resterilized before use.
   F.   Sterile equipment stored in an approved manner and not used within
thirty (30) days after sterilization shall no longer be considered sterile and
shall be resterilized before use.
   G.   An equipment fault manual shall be kept by the licensee and made
available at all times to the village containing a record of all sterilization
equipment failures and remedies taken to correct the failure.
   H.   Sterilizers shall be monitored monthly by an independent testing
laboratory. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-12: DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
The hours of operation of a tattoo and/or body piercing establishment within
the village shall be twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
and shall not be open for business on Mondays. (Ord. 1445, 9-4-2007)
4-12-13: EXISTING ESTABLISHMENTS:
Any person, firm or corporation who is actually engaged in the practice of
tattooing and/or body piercing at the effective date hereof and meets all the
requirements except as to adequacy of facilities, and upon payment of the
prescribed fee, shall be granted a license. Such person shall have thirty (30)
days from the effective date hereof to bring his facilities into compliance
herewith. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-14: INSPECTIONS:
During the business hours of the tattooing and/or body piercing establishment,
the village may conduct periodic inspections for the purpose of determining
whether or not said establishment and the persons performing the art of
tattooing and/or body piercing thereon are in compliance with all applicable
health provisions contained within this chapter and other pertinent ordinances.
It shall be unlawful for any person or operator of a tattooing and/or body
piercing establishment wilfully to prevent or restrain the village building
inspector, village administrator, chief of police, and representative of the
county health department, or any one of them, from entering any licensed
establishment where tattooing and/or body piercing is being performed for the
purpose of inspecting said premises, after proper identification is presented
to the operator. Where the village has reasonable grounds to believe that a
communicable disease has possibly been transmitted at a licensed tattooing and/
or body piercing parlor, it may require testing of the artists and employees.
(Ord. 1230, 2-19-2001)
4-12-15: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Notice And Hearing Required: No license shall be revoked until after
due notice and a hearing shall have been held before the village board of
trustees to determine just cause for such revocation. Notice of such hearing
shall be given in writing and served at least ten (10) days but not more than
twenty (20) days prior to the date of the hearing thereof. The notice shall
state the grounds of the complaint against the holder of such license and shall
designate the time and place where such hearing will be had. Said notice shall
be served upon the license holder by delivering the same personally or leaving
such notice at the place of business or residence of the license holder in the
custody of a person of suitable age and discretion. In the event the license
holder cannot be found and the service of such notice cannot be otherwise made
in the manner herein provided, a copy of such notice shall be mailed,
registered and postage prepaid in full, addressed to the license holder at his
place of business or residence at least ten (10) days prior to the date of such
hearing.
   B.   Grounds: The license of a tattooing and/or body piercing establishment
may be revoked for any legitimate reason, including, without limitation, any
one or more of the following grounds:
      1.   That the holder is addicted to the habitual use of intoxicating
liquors, narcotics or stimulants to such an extent as to incapacitate such
person for the performance of his professional duties for any period of time.
      2.   That the holder is guilty of fraudulent, false, misleading or
deceptive advertising.
      3.   That the holder is guilty of wilful negligence in the practice of
tattooing and/or body piercing or has been guilty of employing, allowing or
permitting any unlicensed person to perform tattooing and/or body piercing in
his establishment.
      4.   That liquor is being sold or consumed within the establishment.
      5.   That the establishment has abandoned the practice of tattooing and/
or body piercing or that the individual licensee has abandoned the same
practices. For the purposes of this subsection B5, "abandonment" shall mean the
activities regulated hereunder, or any of them, have ceased or otherwise not
been conducted for a period of sixty (60) days at the establishment in
question, or where an individual licensee has abandoned the activities
regulated hereunder, or any of them, for a like period.
      6.   That the licensee, whether an establishment or individual, has
violated any provision of this chapter, whether or not an action has been
commenced in circuit court.
   C.   Reissuance Of Revoked License: Any licensee, whether an establishment
or individual, who has had its license revoked three (3) times shall be
ineligible for any license hereunder for a period of five (5) years beginning
with the effective date of the third revocation. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-16: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The requirements of this chapter shall have no application and no effect and
shall not be construed as applying to any person, firm or corporation licensed
by the state to practice medicine or licensed by the state to practice any of
the healing arts. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000)
4-12-17: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
Wherever federal, state, or local laws, ordinances, rules or regulations
conflict with the provisions of this chapter, then the law, ordinance, rule or
regulation which is most strict shall apply, and it shall not be a defense to
an action under this chapter, or to a request for suspension or revocation of
the license(s) provided herein, that this chapter does not specifically
enumerate the proscribed, prohibited or regulated conduct. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-
2000)
4-12-18: PENALTY:
In addition to the revocation and suspension of any license, any person
violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided in section
1-4B-1 of this code, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1192, 3-6-2000;
amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 13
MOVIE THEATERS
SECTION:
4-13-1: Definition
4-13-2: License Required
4-13-3: License Fees
4-13-4: Penalties
4-13-1: DEFINITION:
The term "movie theater", as used in this chapter, is defined to mean one
amphitheater for the seating of patrons either in automobiles or in seats
furnished by the management for the viewing of a movie screen. (1983 Code § 3-
12-2)
4-13-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to own, conduct or
manage within the village any drive-in outdoor or indoor movie theater unless a
license for the same shall have first been obtained from the village. (1983
Code § 3-12-1)
4-13-3: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   A license may be issued by the village clerk upon application and the
payment to the clerk of the following license fees:
      1.   For each outside drive-in movie theater, an annual fee of two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
      2.   For each indoor movie theater, an annual fee of seventy five dollars
($75.00).
   B.   The total license fee to be paid by any applicant shall depend upon the
number of said movie theaters owned or operated thereby. A single building may
house more than one movie theater depending upon the number of amphitheaters
contained therein, and the total license fee due from each applicant shall
depend upon the number of amphitheaters so operated by the applicant. (1983
Code § 3-12-2)
   C.   The license fees provided herein shall become due and payable each year
on May 1; provided, however, that the license fee to be paid by any applicant
commencing the operation of a drive-in outdoor or indoor movie theater, as
referred to herein, after the effective date hereof, shall be prorated
according to the number of months remaining in the fiscal year from the date of
the application. (1983 Code § 3-12-2; amd. 2011 Code)
4-13-4: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-12-3; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 14
ROCK QUARRIES
SECTION:
4-14-1: License And Compliance Required
4-14-2: Application For License
4-14-3: License Fee
4-14-4: Penalties
4-14-1: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate a rock quarry in the village without first
having obtained a license therefor or without full compliance with the
provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 3-16-1)
4-14-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license to operate a rock quarry within the village shall be
made in writing to the village clerk. (1983 Code § 3-16-2)
4-14-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual license fee for the operation of a rock quarry shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per year computed from the date of the issuance of such
license, and a renewal fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall become due
and payable each year upon the anniversary date of said license. (1983 Code §
3-16-3)
4-14-4: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-16-4; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 15
SLAUGHTERHOUSES, PACKINGHOUSES, RENDERIES AND TANNERIES
SECTION:
4-15-1: License Required
4-15-2: Application For License
4-15-3: License Fee
4-15-4: Penalties
4-15-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate a slaughterhouse, packinghouse, rendery, bone
factory, soap factory or tannery in the village without first having obtained a
license therefor. (1983 Code § 3-15-1)
4-15-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license to operate or maintain a slaughterhouse,
packinghouse, rendery, bone factory, soap factory or tannery in the village
shall be made in writing to the village clerk. (1983 Code § 3-15-2)
4-15-3: LICENSE FEE:
Every person, firm or corporation operating or maintaining a slaughterhouse,
packinghouse, rendery, bone factory, soap factory or tannery in the village
shall pay an annual license fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). (1983
Code § 3-15-3)
4-15-4: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-15-4; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 16
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
4-16--1: Applicability Of Provisions
4-16--2: Definitions
4-16--3: License
4-16--4: License Application Requirements
4-16--5: Application Filing; Renewals
4-16--6: License Fees
4-16--7: License Revocation Or Suspension
4-16-8: Limitation On Number Of Video Gaming Licenses
4-16-9: Limitation On Number Of Video Gaming Terminals On Premises
4-16-10: Prohibition
4-16-11: Exceptions
4-16-12: Licensed Establishments
4-16-13: Seizure Of Unauthorized Gambling Devices And Gambling Funds
4-16-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided, shall apply to
all video gaming as hereinafter defined, whether specifically licensed or
regulated under other provisions of this code or other ordinances, or not.
(Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-2: DEFINITIONS:
BOARD: The Illinois Gaming Board.
COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLES: As defined in Section 18b-101 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/18b-101.
LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT: Any business licensed by the State of Illinois to have
or operate a video gaming device in the village, including any licensed
fraternal establishment, licensed veterans establishment, licensed truck stop
establishment and licensed large truck stop establishment as those terms are
defined in the VGA, 230 ILCS 40/5.
LICENSED FRATERNAL ESTABLISHMENT: The location where a qualified fraternal
organization that derives its charter from a national fraternal organization
regularly meets.
LICENSED VETERANS ESTABLISHMENT: The location where a qualified veterans
organization that derives its charter from a national veterans organization
regularly meets.
LICENSED TRUCK STOP ESTABLISHMENT: A facility: (i) that is at least a three-
acre facility with a convenience store; (ii) with separate diesel islands for
fueling commercial motor vehicles; (iii) that sells at retail more than ten
thousand (10,000) gallons of diesel or biodiesel fuel per month; and (iv) with
parking spaces for commercial motor vehicles. The requirement of item (iii) of
this paragraph may be met by showing that estimated future sales or past sales
average at least ten thousand (10,000) gallons per month.
LICENSED LARGE TRUCK STOP ESTABLISHMENT: A facility located within three (3)
road miles from a freeway interchange, as measured in accordance with the
Department of Transportation's rules regarding the criteria for the
installation of business signs: (i) that is at least a three-acre facility with
a convenience store; (ii) with separate diesel islands for fueling commercial
motor vehicles; (iii) that sells at retail more than fifty thousand (50,000)
gallons of diesel or biodiesel fuel per month; and (iv) with parking spaces for
commercial motor vehicles. The requirement of item (iii) of this definition may
be met by showing that estimated future sales or past sales average at least
fifty thousand (50,000) gallons per month.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion
of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including
but not limited to, video poker, line up and blackjack, as authorized by the
board utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which the player may
receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not
include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash or tokens or is for
amusement purposes only. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-3: LICENSE:
   A.   No person, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent, or in
any other capacity, shall operate or permit to be operated any video gaming
terminal, as defined herein, at any premises within the village without first
having obtained a video gaming license from the village. The license provided
for in this article shall permit a licensee to operate video gaming terminals
at the specified establishment.
   B.   No applicant, including any person, either as owner, lessee, manager,
officer or agent, shall be eligible for a video gaming license from the
village, nor shall an existing license holder be entitled to maintain a video
gaming license, unless each of the following requirements are met and continue
to be met:
      1.   The applicant holds the appropriate certificate or license from the
State of Illinois permitting video gaming and is in good standing with same;
      2.   The establishment has been in operation at the location for at least
twelve (12) months at the time the application is filed;
      3.   The establishment must maintain customer seating outside of the
gaming area but within the premises at a ratio of at least five (5) seats for
each permitted video gaming terminal;
      4.   The applicant is not in arrears in any tax, fee or bill due to the
village or State of Illinois;
      5.   The applicant has completed and complies with all the application
requirements set forth in Section
4-16-4 of this article and is not disqualified due to a felony, gambling
offense, or crime of moral turpitude; and
      6.   The establishment is located outside of a residential zoning
district.
   C.   Except for large truck stop establishments, to be eligible to have
video gaming at an establishment, the net terminal income generated at the
establishment from video gaming cannot exceed thirty-three percent (33%) of the
total gross revenues generated.
   D.   Large truck stop and regular truck stop establishments do not need to
meet the requirements set forth in Section
4-16-3(C) of this article.
   E.   A new establishment must meet the requirements of Section
4-16-3B(2) unless the applicant is also a current majority owner of an existing
business at another location, that has been in operation for at least twelve
(12) months, and the business model for the new establishment is proposed to
replicate the existing business location and the applicant can provide
satisfactory evidence detailing that in the last 12-month period video gaming
net terminal income at the other business location did not exceed thirty-three
percent (33%) of the gross revenues.
   F.   The president shall be the approving authority for all licenses. In the
event a licensee or prospective licensee disagrees with any action taken by the
president, an appeal may be made directly to the president and board of
trustees of the village at its next regularly scheduled meeting after written
notice of the action from which an appeal is made. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-4: LICENSE APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
The license applicant shall provide the following information to the village on
a form provided by the village:
   A.   The legal name of the establishment;
   B.   The business name of the establishment;
   C.   The address of the establishment where the video gaming terminals are
to be located;
   D.   The type of establishment, including whether it is classified as a
veteran, fraternal, regular truck stop, large truck stop or liquor
establishment and supporting documentation demonstrating the classification;
   E.   A floor plan, drawn to scale using a computer, detailing the overall
layout of the establishment, including the location and count of dining
seating, the location and count of video gaming terminals and seating for said
terminals, and other significant features of the establishment, including exit
locations, restrooms and other equipment. A high-resolution electronic copy of
the floor plan as well as a paper printed copy (no smaller than 11 inches by 17
inches) shall be submitted at the time of application; hand-drawn floor plans
and floor plans not including a scale will not be accepted;
   F.   The amount of time the establishment has been in business under the
ownership of the applicant at the location where video gaming is proposed to
take place;
   G.   The business office address of the establishment if different from the
address of the establishment;
   H.   In the case of a corporation, limited liability company or trust, the
name and address of an agent authorized and designated to accept service on
behalf of the licensee;
   I.   A phone number for the establishment;
   J.   An e-mail address for the establishment;
   K.   The name and address of every person owning more than a five percent
(5%) share of the establishment;
   L.   The name, address, phone number and e-mail address of any terminal
operator or distributor proposed to own, service or maintain video gaming
terminals at the establishment;
   M.   A copy of the establishment's State of Illinois video gaming license;
   N.   In the case of a corporation, limited liability company or partnership,
a copy of the establishment's state certificate of good standing;
   O.   A statement as to the number of video gaming terminals which the
establishment proposes to have on its premises (not to exceed five (5) for all
establishments);
   P.   A statement that the establishment is not in arrears in any tax, fee or
bill due to the Village or State of Illinois;
   Q.   A statement that the establishment agrees to abide by all state and
federal laws and any local ordinance;
   R.   A statement that no manager or owner with more than five percent (5%)
interest in the establishment has ever been convicted of a felony, a gambling
offense or a crime of moral turpitude. In the event that an establishment
cannot provide such statement, the establishment may apply for a certificate of
rehabilitation from the village president indicating that the individual who
would disqualify the establishment from obtaining the video gaming license has
been rehabilitated and is no longer a threat to violate the law. The village
president may consider the nature of the offense, the length of time since the
offense, the length of time since release from custody and other factors to
determine if the individual has been rehabilitated such that he or she is no
longer likely to commit another offense;
   S.   If the application is for a new establishment based on the business
model of another existing location, information regarding the existing business
location must be provided, including the type of business, the gross receipts
as compared to any video gaming revenue for the prior 12-month period, proof of
the length of time the existing business has been operational and proof of
ownership verifying the applicant's ownership rights; and
   T.   For renewal applications, a report or reports showing its gross annual
revenue for the previous calendar year by category of revenue generated and
showing the percentage of gaming revenue payable to the establishment as
compared to the total gross revenues of the establishment. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-
2025)
4-16-5: APPLICATION FILING; RENEWALS:
   A.   Applications shall be processed by the village clerk on a first come,
first served basis. Every application shall be date and time stamped upon
filing. An application received in the mail shall be considered filed on the
date and time it is opened by the village clerk's department.
   B.   Every video gaming license holder shall be required to file a renewal
application, which may contain the same or similar information as set forth in
Section
4-16-4. Renewal applications shall be due on or before the annual anniversary
of the original application unless that day falls on a holiday, in which case
the application may be received by the clerk on the following business day.
(Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-6: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   The fee for operation of a video gaming terminal shall be two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) per terminal annually. The cost of this fee shall be
shared equally between the terminal operator and the applicable licensed
establishment.
   B.   The application fee is not subject to reimbursement or refund upon
denial of a license. Said fees are not subject to proration or refund and are
due prior to issuance of the license.
   C.   All licenses required by this division shall be prominently displayed
next to the video gaming terminal. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-7: LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
   A.   The president, at any time, may notify any licensee under this division
within five (5) business days of any charge of a violation of any of the
provisions of this article in connection with the operation of any video gaming
terminal. After a hearing presided over by the president, the president may
order the revocation of the license upon a finding that the violation has
occurred, and the license shall thereupon be terminated. The licensee may
appeal the revocation as prescribed in Section
4-16-3(F).
   B.   In the event of the revocation or denial of any license or registration
under this section, such person shall not be issued any license provided for in
this article for one (1) calendar year following the revocation or any appeal
thereof. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-8: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF VIDEO GAMING LICENSES:
There shall be no more than seventeen (17) establishments licensed to operate
video gaming terminals in the village at any given time. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-9: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS ON PREMISES:
   A.   There shall be no more than six (6) video gaming terminals allowed and
permits issued therefore under this article for each licensee at any one
location, other than a licensed large truck stop establishment.
   B.   There shall be no more than ten (10) video gaming terminals allowed and
permits issued therefore under this article for each licensee at any licensed
large truck stop establishment. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-10: PROHIBITION:
Except as otherwise excepted in this article, it shall be unlawful for any
person to gamble within the corporate limits of the village, or for any person
or entity which owns, occupies or controls an establishment within the village
to knowingly permit others to gamble on the premises. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-11: EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prohibit or make unlawful the
following activities or forms of gambling: the keeping, possession, ownership,
use or playing of a video gaming terminal in a licensed establishment, licensed
truck stop establishment, licensed fraternal establishment or licensed veterans
establishment, which is licensed by the board to conduct or allow such specific
activities under the VGA, 230 ILCS 40/1, et seq. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-12: LICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS:
Any business, liquor or food licensee within the corporate limits of the
village that allows gambling to occur on premises in violation of this section
shall be subject to having his/her/its license immediately revoked for a period
of sixty (60) days. Any business, liquor or food licensee within the corporate
limits of the village that allows gambling to occur on premises in violation of
this article a second time shall have his/her/its license permanently revoked
and, thereafter, barred from obtaining any business, liquor or food license
within the village. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
4-16-13: SEIZURE OF UNAUTHORIZED GAMBLING DEVICES AND GAMBLING FUNDS:
Any gambling device which is not authorized by this article shall be subject to
immediate seizure and confiscation by the village. Any money or other thing of
value intrinsically related to acts of gambling not authorized by this article
shall be seized and forfeited as contraband. Disposition of such gambling
devices and funds seized or confiscated shall be made in accordance with the
law. (Ord. 1801, 7-7-2025)
CHAPTER 17
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-17-1: Definitions
4-17-2: Application And Application Fee

4-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings:
BONA FIDE NONPROFIT CLUB: Any fraternal, charitable, religious, benevolent or
any other nonprofit organization having a regular membership association
primarily for mutual social, mental, political and civic welfare, to which
admission is limited to the members and guests and revenue accruing therefrom
to be used exclusively for the benevolent purposes of said organization and
which organization or agency is exempt from taxation, under the internal
revenue laws of the United States as a bona fide fraternal, charitable,
religious benevolent or nonprofit organization.
EMPLOYEE: Any and all persons, other than the masseurs or masseuses, who render
any service to the licensee, who receive compensation directly from the
licensee, and who have no physical contact with the customers or clients.
INSPECTOR: The chief of police, the building inspector, the electrical
inspector, and/or the plumbing and heating inspector, or his authorized
representative.
LICENSEE: The operator of a massage establishment.
MASSAGE: Any method of pressure on or friction against, or stroking, kneading,
rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating of the external soft
parts of the body with hands or with the aid of mechanical electrical apparatus
or appliances with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol,
liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder, creams, lotions, ointments or other
similar preparations commonly used in this practice.
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS: Any establishment having a fixed place of business
where any person, firm, association or corporation engages in or carries on or
permits to be engaged in or carried on any of the activities mentioned in this
chapter. Any establishment engaged in or carrying on, or permitting any
combination of massage and bathhouse shall be deemed a massage establishment.
MASSEUR OR MASSEUSE: Any person, including a trainee, who, for any
consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of "massage" as herein
defined.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint stock company,
corporation or combination of individuals of whatsoever form or character.
PUBLIC BATHHOUSE: Any place, excluding "massage establishments" as herein
defined but including a private club or organization, except as provided in
this section, wherein any person, firm, association or partnership engages in,
conducts or carries on, the business of giving or furnishing Russian, Finnish,
Swedish, hot air, vapor, electric cabinets, steam, mineral, sweat, salt,
Japanese, sauna, fermentation or electric baths or baths of any kind whatever,
excluding ordinary tub baths where an attendant is not required.
RECOGNIZED SCHOOL: Any school or institution of learning which has for its
purpose the teaching of the theory, methods, profession, or work of massage,
which school requires a resident course of study not less than seventy (70)
hours to be given in not more than three (3) calendar months before the student
shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school
or institution of learning following the successful completion of such course
of study or learning. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-2: APPLICATION AND APPLICATION FEE:
Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate or conduct a massage
establishment shall file an application for a massage establishment license
with the village clerk upon a form provided by the village clerk and shall pay
a nonrefundable application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for an original or
renewal application. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-3: APPLICATION FORM FOR MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE:
The application for a massage establishment license shall be under oath and
shall contain the following:
   A.   The address of the proposed massage establishment.
   B.   The name and address of each applicant.
   C.   Such other identification and information necessary to discover the
truth of the matters hereinbefore specified as required to be set forth in the
application.
   D.   If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be
set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation together with the
names and residence addresses of each of the officers, directors, and each
stockholder holding more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the
corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the application shall set forth
the name and the residence address of each of the partners, including limited
partners. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of
this section pertaining to a corporate applicant apply. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-4: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
No license shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter until the
application therefor has been approved in accordance with the provisions of the
foregoing section and applicant has paid a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
which fee shall be in addition to the application fee referred to in section
4-17-2 of this chapter. The license shall terminate on May 1 following the date
of the issuance of the license unless sooner suspended or revoked. (Ord. 1584,
7-15-2013)
4-17-5: REFERRAL OF APPLICATION TO OTHER DEPARTMENTS:
The village clerk, upon receiving an application for a massage establishment
permit, shall refer the application to the building inspector, the electrical
inspector, the plumbing and heating inspector and the village planning board,
who shall inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a massage
establishment and shall make written recommendations to the village
administrator concerning compliance with the regulations that they administer.
(Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-6: FACILITIES REQUIREMENTS:
No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an
inspection by the inspector reveals that the establishment complies with each
of the following minimum requirements:
   A.   Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths, and showers
shall be made waterproof with approved waterproofed materials and shall be
installed in accordance with the Milan building code. Plumbing fixtures shall
be installed in accordance with the Milan plumbing regulations.
      1.   For toilet rooms, toilet room vestibules and rooms containing
bathtubs, there shall be a waterproof floor covering, which will be carried up
all walls to a height of at least six inches (6"). Floor shall be covered up on
base with at least three-fourths inch (3/4") cover. The walls of all toilet
rooms and rooms containing bathtubs shall be finished to a height of six feet
(6') with a smooth, nonabsorbent finish surface of Keene cement, tile, or
similar material.
      2.   Steam rooms and shower compartments shall have waterproof floors,
walls and ceilings approved by the inspector.
      3.   Floors of wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one
or more floor drains properly connected to the sewer. (Exception: Dry heat
rooms with wooden floors need not be provided with pitched floors and floor
drains.)
      4.   A source of hot water must be available within the immediate
vicinity of dry and wet heat rooms to facilitate cleaning.
   B.   Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When five
(5) or more employees and patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the
same time, separate toilet facilities shall be provided. A single water closet
per sex shall be provided for each twenty (20) or more employees or patrons of
the sex on the premises at any one time. Urinals may be substituted for water
closets after one water closet has been provided. All toilet rooms shall be
equipped with self-closing doors opening in the direction of the ingress to the
toilet rooms. Toilets shall be designated as to the sex accommodated therein.
   C.   Lavatories or washbasins provided with hot and cold running water shall
be installed in either the toilet room or the vestibule. Lavatories or
washbasins shall be provided with soap in a dispenser and with sanitary towels.
   D.   All portions of massage establishments and baths shall be provided with
adequate light and ventilation by means of windows or skylights with an area
not less than one-eighth (1/8) of the total floor area, or shall be provided
with approved artificial light and a mechanical operating ventilating system.
When windows or skylights are used for ventilation, at least one-half (1/2) of
the total required window area shall be operable. To allow for adequate
ventilation, cubicles, rooms and areas provided for patrons' use not served
directly by a required window skylight, or mechanical system of ventilation
shall be constructed so that the height of partitions does not exceed seventy
five percent (75%) of the floor to ceiling height of the area in which they are
located.
   E.   All electrical equipment shall be installed in accordance with the
requirements of the Milan electrical regulations. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-7: OPERATING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Every portion of a massage establishment, including appliances,
apparatus, and personnel shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary
condition.
   B.   All employees shall be clean and shall wear suitable clean outer
garments whose use is restricted to the massage establishment. Provision of a
separate dressing room for each sex must be available on the premises with
individual lockers available for each employee and for each customer. Said
lockers shall be equipped with a key lock or number combination locking device.
Doors to such dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing.
   C.   All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered
sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use
thereof and stored in an approved, sanitary manner. No towels or sheets shall
be laundered or dried in any massage establishment unless such establishment is
provided with approved laundry facilities for such laundry and drying. Approved
receptacles shall be provided for the storage of soiled linens and paper
towels.
   D.   Wet and dry rooms, shower compartments, and toilet rooms shall be
thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be
thoroughly cleaned after each use.
   E.   If the massage establishment is in any building used for residential or
sleeping purposes, any room in which the services enumerated in section
4-17-1 of this chapter are provided, is to be used for massage and shall not be
used for residential or sleeping purposes; provided, however, that the
inspector may allow such room to be used for residential or sleeping purposes
if he finds that the health and safety of the patrons of such establishment
will not be jeopardized.
   F.   No service enumerated in section
4-17-1 of this chapter may be carried on within any cubicle, room, booth or any
area within a massage establishment, which is fitted with a door capable of
being locked. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-8: ADVERTISING:
No massage establishment granted a license under the provisions of this chapter
shall place, publish or distribute or cause to be placed, published or
distributed any advertising matter that depicts any portion of the human body
that would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that any service is
available other than those services as described in section
4-17-1 of this chapter, nor shall any massage establishment granted a license
under the provisions of this chapter indicate in the text of such advertising
that any service is available other than those services as described in section
4-17-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-9: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or suspended by
the village administrator after a good cause hearing to determine whether or
not licensee violated any of the provisions of this chapter or any other state
or local laws or ordinances. Good cause hearings before the village
administrator and appeals from the decision of the village administrator shall
follow the same procedure as hearings before, and appeals from, the village
administrator's decision regarding the issuance of licenses. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-
2013)
4-17-10: OPERATOR TO MAINTAIN REGISTER OF EMPLOYEES:
The operator of a massage establishment must maintain a register of all persons
employed as masseurs or masseuses and their permit numbers. Such register shall
be available for inspection at all times during regular business hours. (Ord.
1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-11: NAME AND PLACE OF BUSINESS; CHANGE OF LOCATIONS:
No person granted a license pursuant to this chapter shall operate under any
name or conduct his business under any designation for any location not
specified in his permit. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-12: SALE OR TRANSFER:
Upon sale, transfer or relocation of a massage establishment, the permit and
license therefor shall be null and void; provided, however, that upon the death
or incapacity of the licensee the massage establishment may continue in
business for a reasonable period of time to allow for an orderly transfer of
the permit. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-13: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every masseur or masseuse licensed as such by the village shall display said
license in a conspicuous place within the massage establishment so that the
same may be readily seen by persons entering the premises. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-
2013)
4-17-14: EMPLOYMENT OF MASSEURS AND MASSEUSES:
It shall be the responsibility of the licensee for the massage establishment or
the employer of any persons purporting to act as masseurs and masseuses, to
ensure that each person employed as a masseur or masseuse shall first have
obtained a valid massage license from the state of Illinois. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-
2013)
4-17-15: UNLAWFUL ACTIVITIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to massage any other person or give or
administer any of the other things mentioned in this chapter which violate the
provisions of this chapter or which violate any municipal or state law or
ordinance. Any violation of this provision shall be deemed grounds for
revocation of the license granted hereunder. (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
4-17-16: EXCEPTIONS FROM CHAPTER REGULATIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to hospitals, nursing homes,
sanatoriums, or persons holding an unrevoked medical license, or persons
working under the direction of any such persons or in any such establishments,
nor shall this chapter apply to barbers or cosmetologists lawfully carrying out
their particular profession or business and holding a valid, unrevoked license
or certificate of registration issued by the state of Illinois. (Ord. 1584, 7-
15-2013)
4-17-17: PENALTY:
   A.   Any owner, operator, manager or permittee in charge or in control of a
massage establishment who knowingly employs a person performing as a "masseur
or masseuse", as defined in this chapter, who is not in possession of a valid,
unrevoked massage establishment license or who allows a masseur or masseuse to
perform, operate or practice within such a place of business without having a
valid, unrevoked masseur or masseuse license issued by this village shall be
subject to a fine in a sum not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   B.   Every person, excepting those persons who are specifically exempted by
this chapter, whether acting as an owner or operator of a massage establishment
or an employee of the owner or operator of such establishment who gives or
administers massages or baths as defined in this chapter without first
obtaining a license from the village of Milan so to do or who shall violate any
other provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine in a sum not to
exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1584, 7-15-2013)
TITLE 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1
RESTAURANTS
SECTION:
5-1-1: Definitions
5-1-2: License And Compliance Required
5-1-3: Ineligibility For License
5-1-4: Application For License; Fee; Nontransferability
5-1-5: Food And Drink Regulations
5-1-6: Employees
5-1-7: Premises Requirements
5-1-8: Lavatory Facilities
5-1-9: Water Supply
5-1-10: Utensils And Equipment
5-1-11: Garbage And Refuse
5-1-12: Dancing Prohibited
5-1-13: Inspections
5-1-14: Revocation Of License
5-1-15: Penalties
5-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the term "restaurant" shall be construed to include
any place where food or drink (other than a licensed tavern) is prepared or
served to the public for consumption on the premises, and the term "food" shall
include beverages other than alcoholic liquor. (1983 Code § 3-14-1)
5-1-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate a restaurant in the village without first
having obtained a license therefor or without full compliance with the
provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 3-14-2)
5-1-3: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
No license of any kind under this chapter shall be issued to the following
persons:
   A.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   B.   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   C.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state
of Illinois.
   D.   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a
house of ill fame.
   E.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   F.   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for
cause.
   G.   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   H.   A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall
be qualified to obtain a license.
   I.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   J.   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought,
or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is
to be issued. (1983 Code § 3-14-4)
5-1-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE; NONTRANSFERABILITY:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the village clerk.
The annual license fee shall be thirty five dollars ($35.00), and the same
shall not be transferable. All applications for a license to conduct a
restaurant shall be referred to the license committee of the village board of
trustees, which shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises
to be used and report its findings thereon, recommending or advising against
the issuance of the license. (1983 Code § 3-14-3; amd. Ord. 907, 12-16-1985)
5-1-5: FOOD AND DRINK REGULATIONS:
   A.   Unwholesome Food Prohibited:
      1.   No person, firm or corporation shall offer for sale, or keep for the
purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for
human consumption which is for any reason spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome
and unfit for human consumption. (1983 Code § 3-14-6)
      2.   Samples of food, drink, and other substances may be taken and
examined by a member of the license committee of the village board of trustees
as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or
adulteration. The license committee may condemn and forbid the sale of, or
cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is unwholesome or
adulterated. (1983 Code § 3-14-8)
   B.   Wholesomeness Of Food And Drink:
      1.   All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage,
and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption.
      2.   All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream, and other frozen desserts
served shall be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be
served in the individual original containers in which they were received from
the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing
device; provided, that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be
served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service.
      3.   All oysters, clams, and mussels shall be from approved sources and,
if shucked, shall be kept in the containers in which they were placed at the
shucking plant until used. (1983 Code § 3-14-18)
   C.   Refrigeration: All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at
or below forty one degrees Fahrenheit (41°
   D.   Storage, Display And Serving Of Food And Drink: All food and drink
shall be so stored, displayed, and served as to be protected from dust, flies,
vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet
infection, overhead leakage, and other contamination. No animals or fowls shall
be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored.
All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches, and rodents shall be
used. (1983 Code § 3-14-19)
5-1-6: EMPLOYEES:
   A.   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended
for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to person
and clothing.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier
of any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care or
preparation of any such foods, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such
person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared
or sold, or to deliver such food. (1983 Code § 3-14-7)
5-1-7: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free of litter
or rubbish.
   B.   None of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted
in any room used as living or sleeping quarters.
   C.   Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employee
clothing and shall be kept clean. Soiled linens, coats, and aprons shall be
kept in containers provided for this purpose. (1983 Code § 3-14-20)
5-1-8: LAVATORY FACILITIES:
   A.   Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently
located toilet facilities for its employees, conforming with the provisions of
this code.
   B.   In restaurants hereafter constructed, toilet rooms shall not open
directly into any room in which food, drink, or utensils are handled or stored.
The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing.
   C.   Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair, and
well lighted and ventilated. Hand washing signs shall be posted in each toilet
room used by employees. (1983 Code § 3-14-10)
   D.   Adequate and convenient hand washing facilities shall be provided,
including hot and cold running water, soap, and approved sanitary towels. The
use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after using
the toilet room without first washing his hands. (1983 Code § 3-14-12)
5-1-9: WATER SUPPLY:
Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in which
food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be adequate
and of a safe, sanitary quality. (1983 Code § 3-14-11)
5-1-10: UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Construction And Materials: All multiuse utensils and all show and
display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigeration equipment,
sinks, and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of
a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept
in good repair. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be
used; provided, that solder containing lead may be used for jointing. (1983
Code § 3-14-13)
   B.   Cleaning And Bactericidal Treatment:
      1.   All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters,
shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods, and sinks, shall be kept clean
and free from dust, dirt, insects, and other contaminating material. All cloths
used by waiters, chefs, and other employees shall be clean. Single service
containers shall be used only once.
      2.   All multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly
cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after
each usage. All multiuse utensils used in the preparation or serving of food
and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved
bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths,
if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose.
      3.   No article, polish, or other substance containing any cyanide
preparation or other poisonous material shall be used for the cleansing or
polishing of utensils. (1983 Code § 3-14-14)
   C.   Storage And Handling: After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be
stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust, and other
contamination, as far as practicable. Single service utensils shall be
purchased only in sanitary containers, shall be stored therein in a clean, dry
place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. (1983 Code § 3-14-
15)
5-1-11: GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
All wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be
kept in suitable receptacles in such manner as not to become a nuisance. (1983
Code § 3-14-16)
5-1-12: DANCING PROHIBITED:
Dancing shall not be permitted at any time in any restaurant licensed under
this chapter. (1983 Code § 3-14-21)
5-1-13: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   In case the license committee of the village board of trustees
discovers the violation of any item of sanitation, it shall make a second
inspection after the lapse of such time as it deems necessary for the defect to
be remedied. Any violation of the same requirement of this chapter found on
such second inspection shall authorize immediate license revocation.
   B.   The person operating the restaurant shall, upon request of the license
committee of the village board of trustees, permit access to all parts of the
establishment and shall permit copying any or all records of food purchased.
(1983 Code § 3-14-9)
5-1-14: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any restaurant license may be revoked by the village president for violation of
the provisions of this chapter or for any violation of any provision of this
code relating to the conduct of business, the condition of premises, the
articles sold, or the license required. (1983 Code § 3-14-5)
5-1-15: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a
fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and in the
discretion of the village president, the license may be revoked. (1983 Code §
3-14-22; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 2
NUISANCES
SECTION:
5-2-1: Title
5-2-2: Purpose
5-2-3: Enumeration Of Nuisances
5-2-4: Nuisances Prohibited; Additional Remedies
5-2-5: Notices
5-2-6: Emergency Abatement Of Certain Nuisances
5-2-7: Additional Abatement Provisions; Lien
5-2-8: Penalty
5-2-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the NUISANCE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007)
5-2-2: PURPOSE:
This chapter is declared necessary for the preservation of the public peace,
health, safety and welfare of the people of the village. The purpose of this
chapter is to define, prevent and abate nuisances as authorized by section
11-60-2 of the Illinois municipal code 1 . (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2.
5-2-3: ENUMERATION OF NUISANCES:
Within the village, it is hereby declared a nuisance for any person,
corporation or other association:
   A.   Nuisances Defined By State Law; Nuisances In Fact: To cause any of
those acts or omissions that are declared to be nuisances by the laws of the
state of Illinois, and such as are known as nuisances to the common law, not
hereinafter enumerated in this section or this code, or to cause those acts or
omissions which are nuisances in fact.
   B.   Unsafe, Unsightly Structures: To maintain any building, structure,
street, sign or billboard in an unsafe, hazardous, or unsightly condition.
   C.   Odor: To engage in any activity which causes or produces unreasonably
offensive odors; except, that this subsection shall not apply to those
activities carried on in the public interest.
   D.   Putrid Substances: To maintain or permit any substance on the premises
which is, or may become, putrid or create an unhealthy condition.
   E.   Unhealthy Conditions: To create, allow, maintain or permit any
condition which may endanger the public health.
   F.   Abandoned Refrigerators: To leave or permit standing outside of any
structure, or within any abandoned structure, any abandoned, unattended, or
discarded icebox, refrigerator, or other container which has an airtight door
or lid.
   G.   Littering: To allow, suffer, permit or cause to be dropped, thrown,
discarded, placed or deposited on any public way or public place, or on any
private property when public property may be affected thereby, or on the
private property of another without prior consent by the owner, any paper,
glass, plastic, wood, metal, solid or liquid, vegetable or animal compound,
rubbish, garbage, waste, effluent, junk, debris, litter, or solid, or any
combination thereof, except in a refuse receptacle or landfill site of the
village.
   H.   Barbed Wire: To construct, create, allow, maintain or permit within the
village a fence or barrier consisting or made of barbed wire, or of which
barbed wire is a part, unless the barbed wire commences at least eight feet
(8') above the ground.
   I.   Attractive Nuisances: To create, maintain, or suffer an attractive
nuisance to remain on the premises.
   J.   No License: To fail or refuse to obtain and possess any license
required by this code or other ordinance of the village.
   K.   Continuing Violation: To continue to do any act or omission which
constitutes a violation of this code or other ordinance of the village.
   L.   Zoning Violations: To violate the zoning ordinance of the village.
   M.   Nuisances Defined By This Code: To cause any of those acts or omissions
that are declared by this code in any other section to be nuisances.
   N.   Violation Of Technical Codes: To cause, allow, permit or suffer the
violation of the international building code, international existing building
code, international residential code for one and two-family dwellings,
international property maintenance code or other technical code adopted by the
village.
   O.   Nuisances Declared By Board Of Trustees: To cause any act or omission
which, though not a nuisance as set forth in this section, becomes a nuisance
by reason of the locality, surroundings or manner in which such act or omission
is or is not conducted or managed, and which act or omission is declared to be
a nuisance by resolution of the village board of trustees. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-
2007)
5-2-4: NUISANCES PROHIBITED; ADDITIONAL REMEDIES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to create or maintain, or permit
the creation or maintenance of, a nuisance as described in section
5-2-3 of this chapter upon property under such person's control.
   B.   Proceedings under this chapter shall not prevent the village from
seeking any other judicial remedy to abate any nuisance. Furthermore, payment
of a penalty does not alleviate the violator's responsibility to remedy the
violation. The owners or occupants of the property on which any of the
conditions described in this chapter exist shall be jointly and severally
responsible for the removal and shall be jointly and severally liable for the
expense of its removal in the event it becomes necessary for the village to
remove and dispose of the same. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007)
5-2-5: NOTICES:
   A.   Standard Notice: In the event of a violation under subsections
5-2-3A through M of this chapter, which is not an "emergency" as set forth in
section
5-2-6 of this chapter, the building inspector or any member of the police
department shall issue a notice to the owner or occupant of the property on
which the violation exists, either by regular mail or in person, or by
publication in one issue of a newspaper of general circulation in the village
and a copy of said publication posted on said building if the owner or owners
do not reside in the village or they are unknown. The notice shall provide the
owner or occupant a period of ten (10) calendar days to correct the violation.
In the event the owner or occupant fails to correct the violation in the time
given to correct the same, the owner or occupant will be in violation of this
subsection and may be issued an ordinance violation citation. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-
2007)
   B.   Notice Of Violation Of Technical Codes: In the event of a violation
under subsection
5-2-3N of this chapter, which is not an "emergency" as set forth in section
5-2-6 of this chapter, the building inspector shall issue a notice to the owner
or occupant of the property on which the violation exists, either by regular
mail or in person, or by publication in one issue of a newspaper of general
circulation in the village and a copy of said publication posted on said
building if the owner or owners do not reside in the village or they are
unknown. The notice shall provide the owner or occupant a period of not less
than ten (10) calendar days to correct the violation. In the event the owner or
occupant fails to correct the violation in the time given to correct the same,
the owner or occupant will be in violation of this subsection and may be issued
an ordinance violation citation. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007; amd. 2011 Code)
   C.   Alternative Notice: Whenever the board of trustees shall, by
resolution, declare a nuisance to exist pursuant to subsection
5-2-3O of this chapter, which nuisance is not an "emergency" as set forth in
section
5-2-6 of this chapter, the village clerk shall issue in a notice and order of
abatement, which shall be served upon the owner or owners of said building
residing in the village, or published in one issue a newspaper of general
circulation in the village and a copy of said publication posted on said
building if the owner or owners do not reside in the village or are unknown.
The notice shall provide the owner or owners a period of ten (10) calendar days
to correct the violation. In the event the owner or occupant fails to correct
the violation in the time given to correct same, the owner or occupant will be
in violation of this subsection and may be issued an ordinance violation
citation. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007)
5-2-6: EMERGENCY ABATEMENT OF CERTAIN NUISANCES:
When a nuisance, as defined by section
5-2-3 of this chapter, exists and the nuisance causes or threatens imminent
danger or great peril to persons or property, the nuisance may be immediately
abated by the village, using the following procedure:
   A.   The building inspector shall set forth in writing his or her findings
that such nuisance causes or threatens imminent danger or great peril to
persons or property, and that an emergency exists.
   B.   A copy of the building inspector's findings made under subsection A of
this section shall be placed on file in the office of the village clerk.
   C.   The building inspector shall immediately issue a notice directed to the
owner or occupant of the premises on which the nuisance exists, directing the
owner or occupant to immediately abate the nuisance.
   D.   The notice issued pursuant to subsection C of this section shall be
served upon the owner or occupant of the premises upon which the nuisance
exists. The notice may be served by an officer or employee of the village. In
the event that the owner or occupant of the premises is not found, the notice
may be posted on the premises on which the nuisance exists.
   E.   Upon being served with a notice to abate a nuisance as provided in
subsection D of this section, the owner or occupant of the premises on which
the nuisance is located shall immediately abate the nuisance. The failure of
the owner or occupant to immediately abate the nuisance upon service or posting
of the notice shall be a violation of this code.
   F.   In the event that the owner or occupant of a premises on which a
nuisance is ordered to be abated under this section does not immediately abate
the nuisance, the appropriate village department shall immediately abate the
nuisance. The cost of the abatement by the village shall be assessed against
the property on which the nuisance existed, and shall be collected as other
special assessments. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007)
5-2-7: ADDITIONAL ABATEMENT PROVISIONS; LIEN:
In addition to the foregoing, the village may abate the nuisance in any
reasonable manner including the removal of articles constituting the nuisance
and may collect from such violators the reasonable cost thereof. The cost of
removal shall become a lien on the real estate affected; provided, that a
notice of lien is filed in the office of the recorder of deeds within sixty
(60) days of the completion of the abatement of said nuisance. The lien notice
shall set forth a description of the real estate involved, the amount of money
representing the costs and expenses incurred in the abatement of the nuisance,
and the dates when said costs and expenses were incurred by the village. (Ord.
1428, 5-7-2007)
5-2-8: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall
be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4B-1 of this code. Each and every consecutive subsequent day that the
nuisance is not removed will constitute a separate violation and will be
subject to another separate fine in the minimum amount as provided in said
section
1-4B-1 without further notice. See title 1, chapter 4, article C of this code
for no contest procedures. (Ord. 1428, 5-7-2007; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
5-3-1: Classification And Definitions
5-3-2: Container Requirements
5-3-3: Prohibited Deposits
5-3-4: Collection Requirements
5-3-5: Theft Of Recyclables Prohibited
5-3-6: Penalty
5-3-1: CLASSIFICATION AND DEFINITIONS:
There shall be and are hereby established four (4) classifications of garbage
and refuse:
   A.   Residential Garbage And Refuse: Garbage and refuse generated by those
premises used exclusively for single-family or multiple-family dwellings, of
the type normally associated with the operation of a household including food
waste and paper goods, etc.
   B.   Residential Recyclable Material: Approved paper, cardboard, plastic and
glass.
   C.   Residential Yard Waste: Yard waste generated by a residential premises.
   D.   Commercial Garbage And Refuse: All garbage and refuse which does not
meet the definition of residential garbage and refuse or residential yard waste
shall be considered commercial garbage and refuse, including:
      1.   Waste generated by those premises used in whole or in part for the
performance of services, manufacture of a product, entertainment, or wholesale
or retail business of any nature;
      2.   Bulk items which do not fit within the standard trash container;
      3.   Excess or discarded construction materials or waste from remodeling;
      4.   Appliances;
      5.   Biomedical or hazardous waste. (Ord. 1608, 8-18-2014)
5-3-2: CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Definition: For the purpose of this chapter, the words "collection day"
shall mean the day advertised by the village as the next garbage and refuse
collection day for the property of the owner or occupant.
   B.   Container Required: It shall be the duty of every owner, or his agent
or occupant, of any house, building, flat, apartment or tenement where people
reside, board or lodge in the village, or where animal or vegetable matter is
prepared or served, to at all times maintain in good order and repair a
receptacle for garbage and refuse, constructed in accordance with the
provisions of subsection C of this section.
   C.   Specifications: Containers for residential garbage shall be either
forty eight (48) gallon or ninety six (96) gallon capacity wheeled containers
of the type supplied by the village of Milan. One container per household will
be provided by the village of Milan for collection of residential garbage
without charge. Additional containers may be provided by the village of Milan
for a reasonable fee. In addition to a container for residential garbage as
described above, each resident shall also be provided one approved either forty
eight (48) gallon or ninety six (96) gallon capacity wheeled blue container for
recyclable materials.
   D.   Yard Waste: Yard waste shall be placed in approved yard waste bags as
provided at local retail stores and placed at the street curb line for pick up
with a proper yard waste sticker affixed to each bag. Yard waste stickers shall
be available for purchase from the village clerk for a reasonable fee.
   E.   Placement Of Residential Garbage Containers:
      1.   Residential garbage containers shall be placed at the street curb
line on collection day in a location with three feet (3') of empty space on
each side of the container. The placement of residential garbage containers at
the street curb line more than twenty four (24) hours prior to collection day
is hereby prohibited.
      2.   Recyclable containers shall be placed at the street curb line on
collection day in a location with three feet (3') of empty space on each side
of the container. The placement of recyclable containers at the street curb
line more than twenty four (24) hours prior to collection day is hereby
prohibited.
      3.   Yard waste bags shall be placed at the street curb line for pick up
with a proper yard waste sticker affixed. (Ord. 1608, 8-18-2014)
5-3-3: PROHIBITED DEPOSITS:
No garbage or refuse of any kind shall be deposited in any street, alley or
public way, except as provided in this chapter, and no such refuse shall be so
placed that it can be blown about or scattered by the wind. (Ord. 1608, 8-18-
2014)
5-3-4: COLLECTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Residential Garbage: The collection of residential garbage and refuse
shall be made by the village at least once each week, provided the material is
properly stored for collection in containers as provided in this chapter. There
shall be no additional service charge for the collection of residential garbage
other than that which is levied as a garbage tax.
   B.   Recyclable Materials: The collection of recyclable materials shall be
made by Allied Waste Of Bettendorf, Iowa, at least once every two (2) weeks,
provided the material is properly stored for collection in the containers as
provided in this chapter. There shall be an additional service charge of four
dollars ($4.00) per residence per month for the collection of recyclable
material in addition to the levy of a garbage tax.
   C.   Yard Waste: The collection of residential yard waste shall be made by
the village upon request of the resident. The fee for the collection of
residential yard waste shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year plus one
dollar forty five cents ($1.45) per sticker for each bag of residential yard
waste. The cost of both the twenty five dollar ($25.00) per year fee and the
cost of each one dollar forty five cents ($1.45) shall be a service charge in
addition to the levy of a garbage tax.
   D.   Commercial Garbage And Refuse: The collection of commercial garbage and
refuse shall be contracted for privately, by the owner or operator of the
premises. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of the premises to see
to it that said collection is made in a timely manner, which in no event should
be longer than seven (7) days from the time that such commercial garbage and
refuse accumulates. The village of Milan may provide for the pick up of
residential bulk items, which do not fit within the standard trash container at
the discretion of the head of the department of public works. The village of
Milan may charge a reasonable fee, which in no event shall be less than five
dollars ($5.00) to cover the cost of labor associated with the pick up of any
residential bulk items. Unreasonably large bulk item pick ups may be charged
for the extra time and/or expense caused by any such pick up. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, the village clerk may waive the fee for the collection of
residential bulk items two (2) times each year per residence, provided however
that pick ups that create an unreasonable amount of time or expense to the
village of Milan shall not be waived and may be charged an additional amount as
set forth above. (Ord. 1608, 8-18-2014)
5-3-5: THEFT OF RECYCLABLES PROHIBITED:
