13-6-7: Damage To Underground Facilities
13-6-8: Trimming Or Removal Of Trees
13-6-9: Moving Facilities
13-6-10: Work Performed By Others
13-6-11: Liability For Damages
13-6-1: PERMITS, LICENSES AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Prior to commencing any construction in the village, a grantee must
obtain all necessary permits and licenses required by federal, state and
village laws, ordinances and rules, and pay all associated fees. Further, a
grantee shall comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules, and standards
relating to the construction, operation and maintenance of a cable television
system.
   B.   At a minimum, and without limitation, a grantee shall adhere to all
building, electrical and zoning codes currently or hereafter in force in the
village. The construction, installation, and maintenance of the cable system
shall be effectuated by the grantee in a manner that is consistent with the
laws, ordinances and construction standards of the state of Illinois, the
occupational safety and health administration, the national electrical safety
code, national electrical code and the FCC, to the extent applicable, as well
as all other applicable laws, rules, regulations and ordinances that are
generally applicable and promulgated pursuant to the village's lawful police
power. All open connections on splitters, couplers and other devices shall be
properly terminated. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-2: MINIMUM INTERFERENCE:
All of the grantee's construction, installation, operation, repair and
maintenance, and the arrangement of its lines, cables and other appurtenances,
on both public and private property, shall be conducted in such a manner as to
cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of the
public and any property owners that may be affected. In the event of any such
interference, the village may require the removal of the grantee's lines,
cables and appurtenances from the public rights of way in question, at the sole
expense of the grantee. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-3: REPAIR OF PROPERTY:
The grantee shall promptly repair and restore any village or private property
which may be damaged as a result of the construction, installation, operation,
repair or maintenance of the cable system. Any such property damaged or
destroyed shall be promptly repaired and restored by the grantee, at the
grantee's sole cost and expense and to the reasonable satisfaction of the
village, to its condition prior to being damaged or shall be replaced by the
grantee with equivalent property. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-4: INSTALLATION OF POLES:
The grantee shall not erect, for any reason, any pole on or along any public
rights of way in an existing aerial utility system without the advance written
approval of the village. If additional poles in an existing aerial route are
required, the grantee shall negotiate, as needed, with the utility for the
installation of the needed poles. Any such addition shall require the advance
written approval of the village. The grantee shall negotiate the lease of pole
space and facilities from the existing pole owners for all aerial construction,
under mutually acceptable terms and conditions. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-5: RESERVATION OF STREET RIGHTS:
Nothing in this title shall be construed to prevent the village from
constructing storm or sanitary sewers, grading, paving, repairing or altering
any public rights of way, or laying down, repairing or removing water mains or
gas lines, traffic signal control systems, village fiber plant, or constructing
or establishing any public utility, service or other public work that the
village may operate or undertake now or in the future. All such work shall be
done, insofar as practicable, in such manner as not to obstruct, injure or
prevent the free use and operation of poles, wires, conduits, conductors, pipes
or appurtenances of the grantee. If the village, in its sole discretion, shall
determine that the grantee will interfere with the construction or repair of
any public right of way or public improvement, whether it be construction,
repair or removal of a sewer or water main, the improvement of any public way
or any other public improvement, then all such property of the grantee shall be
removed or replaced, or temporarily disconnected, in such manner as shall be
directed by the village so that the same shall not interfere with the public
works of the village. Such removal or replacement shall be at the expense of
grantee; provided, however, that nothing in this title shall preclude the
grantee from seeking reimbursement for removal or replacement costs from any
public funds generally available to rights of way users for the reimbursement
of such costs. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-6: UNDERGROUND OR ABOVEGROUND INSTALLATION:
In those areas within the village where cable system facilities are currently
placed underground, all cable system facilities shall remain or be placed
underground. In areas where either telephone or electric utility facilities are
aboveground at the time of installation, the grantee may install its cable
system facilities aboveground; provided, that at such time as both electric and
telephone utility facilities are placed underground, the grantee shall likewise
place its cable system facilities without cost to the village or if village
requires undergrounding in the future pursuant to a separate ordinance. The
village shall not, however, pay the costs for underground facility placement or
otherwise grant incentives to electric and telephone utilities for underground
facility placement without providing the same terms or incentives to the
grantee; provided, however, that state or federal requirements or mandates
imposed upon the grantor shall not be construed as incentives to any such
utility. Nothing contained in this section shall require a grantee to
construct, operate and maintain underground any ground mounted appurtenances;
except, that the grantee shall take steps to minimize the number and visual
impact of such facilities. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001; amd. 2011 Code)
13-6-7: DAMAGE TO UNDERGROUND FACILITIES:
   A.   The village shall not be responsible for any cuts or damage to buried
or underground facilities of a grantee that are not clearly marked or cannot be
located through the Illinois one call service.
   B.   The grantee shall provide the village detailed strand and trench maps
in both paper and a mutually agreed upon electronic format of all new
underground and buried cable facilities upon activation of such sections of the
system.
   C.   The grantee shall provide a contact number for the village to call in
emergency situations requiring an immediate response on the part of the village
or a village utility. If the grantee does not properly and effectively identify
the precise location of its facilities within one hour of an emergency call
from the village or village utility, the village shall not be responsible for
damage to the grantee's facilities. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-8: TRIMMING OR REMOVAL OF TREES:
The grantee shall have the right to remove, trim, cut and keep clear of its
poles, cables, underground conduits and related equipment the trees in and
along the public streets, but in the exercise of such right, the grantee shall
not cut such trees to any greater extent than is reasonably necessary for the
construction, erection, installation, maintenance and use of cable system
equipment. Except in emergency situations, the grantee shall not remove, trim
or cut such trees from any public streets without first providing reasonable
notice to the village of its intention to do so, such notice to be delivered
not less than ten (10) days in advance. The grantee shall compensate the
village or any private owners of such trees for any damage proximately caused
by the grantee's negligent conduct. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-9: MOVING FACILITIES:
The grantee, on the request of the village, or any person holding a building
permit issued by the village or any permit issued by an appropriate state
agency, shall temporarily move its wires, cables, poles or other cable system
facilities to permit the moving of large objects, vehicles, buildings or other
structures. The expense of such temporary moves shall be paid to the grantee by
the person requesting the same, and the grantee shall have the authority to
require such payment in advance. The grantee shall be given not less than
thirty (30) days' advance notice to arrange for such temporary moves. (Ord.
1241, 6-18-2001)
13-6-10: WORK PERFORMED BY OTHERS:
   A.   A grantee shall make available to the village, upon reasonable request,
the company names and business addresses of any person, other than the grantee,
which performs services pursuant to a franchise agreement; provided, however,
that all provisions of this title remain the responsibility of grantee.
   B.   To the extent applicable, all provisions of this title shall apply to
any subcontractors or others performing any work or services pursuant to the
provisions of a franchise agreement on behalf of a grantee. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-
2001)
13-6-11: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
Nothing contained in this title shall relieve any person from liability arising
out of the failure to exercise reasonable care to avoid injuring the grantee's
facilities while performing any work connected with grading, regrading or
changing the line of any public way or with the construction or reconstruction
of any sewer or water system or utility system. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
CHAPTER 7
OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE
SECTION:
13-7-1: Open Books And Records
13-7-2: Communications With Regulatory Agencies
13-7-3: Reports
13-7-4: Strand And Trench Maps
13-7-5: Service Contract And Subscriber Information
13-7-1: OPEN BOOKS AND RECORDS:
Each grantee shall cooperate with the grantor with respect to the grantor's
administration of this title and its applicable franchise agreement. The
grantor shall have the right to inspect, at any time during normal business
hours, all books, records, maps, plans, revenue statements, showing all "gross
revenues" (as defined in section
13-1-3 of this title), and signed and certified by an independent certified
public accountant as to their accuracy, service complaint logs, performance
test results, and other existing like materials of a grantee that relate to the
operation of a grantee's system and that are reasonably necessary to the
grantor's enforcement or administration of this title and/or a franchise
agreement. The grantee shall not be required to maintain any books or records
for franchise compliance purposes longer than five (5) years. Upon request, the
grantor will treat designated information disclosed by a grantee as
confidential to the extent permissible under state and federal law. (Ord. 1241,
6-18-2001)
13-7-2: COMMUNICATIONS WITH REGULATORY AGENCIES:
A grantee shall provide the grantor with timely notice of all petitions,
applications, communications, and reports submitted by each grantee to the FCC,
securities and exchange commission, or any other federal or state regulatory
commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matters directly
related to the franchise or system operations. Copies of the above referenced
documents shall be made available in a reasonable time to the grantor upon
request. Copies of responses from the above regulatory agencies to each grantee
likewise shall be made available promptly to the grantor upon request. If the
village is specifically named in any such pleading or response, the village
shall automatically be furnished a copy. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-7-3: REPORTS:
   A.   Annual Reports:
      1.   Upon request, each grantee shall make available to the grantor, at
the end of each of the applicable grantee's fiscal year during the term of a
franchise agreement, the following:
         a.   A revenue statement certified by an officer or certified public
accountant of the grantee showing, in such detail as acceptable to the grantor,
the gross revenues of the grantee for the preceding fiscal year;
         b.   A current list of names and addresses of each officer and
director and other management personnel of the grantee;
         c.   A copy of all documents that directly relate to the grantee's
system that were filed with any federal, state, or local agencies during the
preceding fiscal year and that were not previously filed with the grantor;
         d.   A statement of the grantee's current billing practices and
charges;
         e.   A copy of the grantee's current subscriber service contract; and
         f.   A copy of annual reports, if any, to stockholders for the
operating company and parent company.
      2.   The grantor and its agents and representatives may and shall have
the authority to arrange for and conduct an audit of and copy the books and
records necessary for the enforcement of the franchise agreement of any grantee
once per calendar year; provided, however, that if a material issue of
noncompliance is discovered through such audit or other means, the grantor
shall have the authority to conduct audits on a more frequent basis until a
satisfactory record of compliance is established. A grantee shall first be
given twenty (20) calendar days' notice of the audit, the description of and
purpose for the audit, and a description, to the best of the grantor's ability,
of the books, records, and documents that the grantor wants to review.
   B.   Index Of Reports:
      1.   Each grantee shall compile and maintain an index of reports that
shall list all reports, documents, and filings that it has prepared with
respect to the system over the course of the past two (2) years as a result of
the requirements of the FCC or this title, including technical system testing,
and proof of performance reports and customer service compliance measurements,
and shall provide a copy of such index of reports to the grantor every six (6)
months, and more frequently upon request.
      2.   Each grantee shall make a copy of any reports or documents listed in
the index of reports available to the grantor upon request.
   C.   Additional Reports: Upon request, each grantee shall prepare and
furnish to the grantor, at the times and in the form prescribed, such
additional reports with respect to its operations, affairs, transactions, or
property which are reasonable and in the sole discretion of the grantor are
necessary. Any such reporting requests may not include any information
determined to be confidential or proprietary for competitive reasons as
reasonably determined by the grantee. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-7-4: STRAND AND TRENCH MAPS:
   A.   All lines, equipment, and connections in, over, under, and upon the
right of way and private property within the village, wherever situated or
located, shall at all times be kept and maintained in a safe and suitable
condition and in good order and repair.
   B.   Upon completion of any construction, upgrade or rebuild, the grantee
shall provide the grantor a copy of all strand and trench maps. (Ord. 1241, 6-
18-2001)
13-7-5: SERVICE CONTRACT AND SUBSCRIBER INFORMATION:
   A.   Each grantee shall have authority to promulgate such rules,
regulations, terms, and conditions governing the conduct of its business as
shall be reasonably necessary to enable the grantee to exercise its rights and
perform its obligations under this title and any franchise agreement and to
assure uninterrupted service to all of its subscribers; provided, such rules,
regulations, terms, and conditions shall not be in conflict with the provisions
of this title, a franchise agreement, federal, state and/or village law, or any
applicable rules and regulations.
   B.   Every grantee shall submit to the grantor the form of its general
subscriber contract. If no written contract exists, a grantee shall file with
the village a document completely and concisely stating the terms of the
residential subscriber contract(s) offered, specifically including the length
of the subscriber contract(s). The length and terms of any general subscriber
contract shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours;
provided, however, that specific subscriber contracts previously executed shall
not be so available. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
CHAPTER 8
GENERAL FINANCIAL AND INSURANCE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
13-8-1: Franchise Fee
13-8-2: Security Fund, Bonds And Insurance
13-8-3: Penalties Procedure
13-8-1: FRANCHISE FEE:
   A.   As compensation for a franchise, and in consideration of permission to
use the rights of way of the village for the construction, operation and
maintenance of a cable system within the village, and to defray the costs of
regulation, each grantee shall pay to the grantor an annual amount equal to
five percent (5%) of the grantee's gross revenues.
   B.   Payments due the grantor under this section shall be computed quarterly
for the preceding quarter. Each quarter payment shall be due and payable no
later than forty five (45) days after the end of the preceding quarter. Unless
the franchise agreement provides otherwise, at the request of the village, the
grantee shall electronically deposit payments into a financial institution
designated by the village. Any associated charges for electronic transfer may
be credited against the franchise fee. Verification of this deposit shall be
provided to the village treasurer. Each payment shall be accompanied by a brief
report by a grantee showing the basis for the computation and a "franchise fee
worksheet" listing all of the sources of revenues attributable to the operation
of the grantee's system. A grantee that is subject to a municipal
telecommunications consent fee shall maintain separate accounts and records
with respect to the calculation and payment of such fees.
   C.   No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as an accord that the
amount paid is in fact the correct amount, nor shall such acceptance of payment
be construed as a release of any claim the grantor may have for further sums
payable under the provisions of this title or a franchise agreement. All
amounts paid shall be subject to audit and recomputation by the grantor or its
designee at any time during any calendar year (but no more than once per
calendar year) upon twenty (20) calendar days' notice, including information on
the specific documents requested to be reviewed. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-8-2: SECURITY FUND, BONDS AND INSURANCE:
   A.   Each grantee shall maintain a security fund or performance bond with
the village to ensure compliance with this title and the applicable franchise
agreement in an amount and in a manner as set forth in the grantee's franchise
agreement in a mutually agreed upon form as specified in the franchise
agreement.
   B.   Each grantee shall maintain bonds and insurance with the village in
amounts and in a manner as set forth in the grantee's franchise agreement. Each
grantee also shall be required to indemnify the village in a manner as set
forth in the grantee's franchise agreement. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-8-3: PENALTIES PROCEDURE:
   A.   Whenever the grantor has reason to believe that a grantee has violated
any provision of a franchise agreement or this title, the grantor shall first
notify the grantee of the violation and demand correction within a reasonable
time, which shall not be less than twenty (20) days in the case of the failure
of a grantee to pay any sum or other amount due the grantor under a franchise
agreement, and thirty (30) days in all other cases. If a grantee fails to
correct the violation within the time prescribed, or if a grantee is unable to
correct the violation and fails to commence corrective action within the time
prescribed and to diligently remedy such violation thereafter, the grantee
shall then be given written notice of not less than twenty (20) days of a
public hearing to be held before the board. Said notice shall indicate with
reasonable specificity the violation alleged to have occurred.
   B.   At the public hearing, the board shall hear and consider all relevant
evidence and thereafter render findings and a decision based upon the evidence.
Any such hearing must, at a minimum, provide the grantee a full and fair
opportunity to be heard by the village.
   C.   In the event the village finds that a grantee has corrected the
violation or promptly commenced correction of such violation after notice
thereof from the grantor and is diligently proceeding to fully remedy the
violation, or that no violation has occurred, the proceedings shall terminate,
and no penalty or other sanction shall be imposed.
   D.   In the event the village finds that a violation exists and that a
grantee has not corrected the same in a satisfactory manner, the village may
impose liquidated damages from the security fund or performance bond as set out
in the franchise agreement.
   E.   If the grantor elects to assess liquidated damages, then such election
shall constitute the grantor's exclusive remedy for a period of sixty (60)
days. Thereafter, if a grantee remains in noncompliance, the grantor may pursue
any other available remedy.
   F.   In the event that a franchise is canceled or terminated by reason of
the default of a grantee, the security fund deposited pursuant to a franchise
agreement shall remain in effect and available to the grantor until all pending
claims or penalties are resolved or settled, after which point, any remaining
amounts in the security fund shall revert to the possession of the grantee.
   G.   The rights reserved to the grantor with respect to the security fund
are in addition to all other rights of the grantor, whether reserved by a
franchise agreement, this title, or authorized by law, and no action,
proceeding, or exercise of a right with respect to such security fund shall
affect any other right the grantor may have.
   H.   In instances of repeated violations, whether remedied or not, the
grantor shall serve special notice outlining additional remediation
requirements. Failure to cure, as measured by repeated instances of the same
violation, is evidence of an evasive practice and may lead to revocation under
chapter 9 of this title. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
CHAPTER 9
REVOCATION OF FRANCHISE
SECTION:
13-9-1: Grounds For Revocation
13-9-2: Notice Of Revocation
13-9-3: Hearing
13-9-4: Decision
13-9-5: Appeal
13-9-1: GROUNDS FOR REVOCATION:
In addition to any rights in this title or a franchise agreement, the grantor
reserves the right to revoke the franchise and all rights and privileges
pertaining thereto in the event that:
   A.   A grantee substantially violates any material provision of this title
or the franchise agreement;
   B.   A grantee attempts to evade any of the provisions of this title or the
franchise agreement;
   C.   A grantee practices an act of fraud or deceit upon the grantor; or
   D.   The grantee becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts or
is adjudged bankrupt. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-9-2: NOTICE OF REVOCATION:
Whenever the grantor has reason to believe that there may be grounds for
revocation of a franchise, the grantor shall first notify the grantee in
writing of its basis for believing grounds for revocation exist. Such notice
shall indicate with reasonable specificity the grounds for revocation that are
believed to exist so that the grantee may have a reasonable opportunity to cure
or otherwise address the grounds. If a grantee fails to adequately cure or
address the purported grounds for revocation within thirty (30) days of such
notice, then the grantor may, upon thirty (30) days' written notice to the
grantee, commence a public administrative hearing to determine whether there
exists grounds for revocation. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-9-3: HEARING:
The administrative hearing shall be conducted so as to protect the full due
process rights of the parties and provide for, at a minimum, the right to have
counsel, the right to call and cross examine witnesses, the right to a full
transcript of the proceedings, and the right to have the matter heard before a
mutually agreed upon third party hearing officer. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-9-4: DECISION:
After the close of the hearing, the grantor or the designated hearing officer
shall issue a written decision based on the record of the proceedings, stating
with specificity the findings and reasons supporting the decision. (Ord. 1241,
6-18-2001)
13-9-5: APPEAL:
Upon revocation, a grantee shall have a period of sixty (60) days subsequent to
the date of the formal adoption of a revocation of the franchise by the village
within which to file an appeal with a court of competent jurisdiction. During
the appeal period, the franchise shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord.
1241, 6-18-2001)
CHAPTER 10
FORECLOSURE AND RECEIVERSHIP
SECTION:
13-10-1: Foreclosure
13-10-2: Receivership
13-10-1: FORECLOSURE:
Upon the foreclosure or other judicial sale of all or a part of a system, or
upon the termination of any lease covering all or part of a system, a grantee
shall notify the grantor of such fact, and such notification shall be treated
as a notification that a change in control of the grantee has taken place, and
the provisions of this title governing the consent to transfer or change in
ownership shall apply without regard to how such transfer or change in
ownership occurred. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-10-2: RECEIVERSHIP:
The grantor shall have the right to cancel a franchise agreement one hundred
twenty (120) days after the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over
and conduct the business of a grantee, whether in receivership, reorganization,
bankruptcy, or other action or proceeding, unless such receivership or
trusteeship shall have been vacated prior to the expiration of said one hundred
twenty (120) days, or unless:
   A.   Within one hundred twenty (120) days after its election or appointment,
the receiver or trustee has fully complied with all the provisions of the
grantee's franchise agreement and this title and remedied all defaults
thereunder; and
   B.   Such receiver or trustee, within said one hundred twenty (120) days,
has executed an agreement, duly approved by a court having jurisdiction,
whereby such receiver or trustee assumes and agrees to be bound by each and
every provision of this title and the applicable franchise agreement. (Ord.
1241, 6-18-2001)
CHAPTER 11
PURCHASE OF SYSTEM; SALE OR TRANSFER OF FRANCHISE
SECTION:
13-11-1: Purchase Of System
13-11-2: Sale Or Transfer Of Franchise
13-11-1: PURCHASE OF SYSTEM:
   A.   Grantor's Right To Purchase System: The grantor shall be entitled to a
right of first refusal of any bona fide offer to purchase the system made to a
grantee only if such offer includes only the cable system operated in the
village and is not linked in any way to the sale of a cable system in another
community. "Bona fide offer", as used in this subsection, means an offer
received by a grantee that it intends to accept. The village shall have thirty
(30) days to notify the grantee of its intent to purchase the system. Upon
receipt of such notice, the grantee shall have thirty (30) days to provide the
village with all information reasonably necessary for the village to conduct a
due diligence with respect to the purchase of the system. The village must have
readily available funds necessary to pay the full amount of the bona fide offer
no later than seventy five (75) days following notice to the grantee of its
intent to purchase the system. Consistent with section
13-11-2 of this chapter, the village shall notify the grantee in writing within
thirty (30) days of notice of the bona fide offer of its decision whether to
purchase the system. This subsection shall not apply to a transfer to a wholly
owned affiliate subsidiary, nor parent company, of the grantee.
   B.   Purchase By Grantor Upon Termination Or Revocation Of Franchise: The
grantor may, in accordance with and to the extent permitted by 47 USC section
547, upon the payment of a fair valuation, ascertain, purchase, condemn,
acquire, take over, and hold the property and plant of a grantee, in whole or
in part, on the following conditions:
      1.   Upon revocation of a franchise, such valuation shall not include any
sum attributable to the value of the franchise itself, and plant and property
shall be valued according to an equitable price at the time of revocation.
      2.   At the expiration of a franchise agreement, such valuation shall be
at fair market value, exclusive of the value attributed to the franchise
itself.
      3.   In the event the grantor shall terminate a franchise pursuant to the
provisions of this title or a franchise agreement, and commenced operation of
the system, the grantor shall reimburse the grantee for the fair market value
of the system. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-11-2: SALE OR TRANSFER OF FRANCHISE:
   A.   No grantee shall sell, transfer, lease, assign, sublet, or dispose of,
in whole or in part, an interest in or control of a franchise or cable system
or any of the rights or privileges granted by a franchise agreement without the
prior written consent of the grantor, which consent shall not be unreasonably
denied or delayed and may be denied only upon a good faith finding by the
grantor that the proposed transferee lacks the legal, technical, or financial
qualifications to consummate the transaction and operate the system so as to
perform its obligations under this title and the applicable franchise
agreement. This section shall not apply to sales of property or equipment in
the normal course of business. Consent from the grantor shall not be required
for a transfer in trust, mortgage, or other instrument of hypothecation, in
whole or in part, to secure an indebtedness, or for a pro forma transfer to a
corporation, partnership, or other entity controlling, controlled by, or under
common control with a grantee.
   B.   The following events shall be deemed to be a sale, assignment, or other
transfer of an interest in or control of a franchise or cable system requiring
compliance with this section: 1) the sale, assignment, or other transfer of all
or a majority of a grantee's assets; 2) the sale, assignment, or other transfer
of capital stock or partnership, membership, or other equity interests in a
grantee by one or more of its existing shareholders, partners, members, or
other equity owners so as to create a new controlling interest in a grantee; 3)
the issuance of additional capital stock or partnership membership or other
equity interest by a grantee so as to create a new controlling interest in a
grantee; and 4) a grantee's agreement to transfer management or operation of
the grantee or the system to an unaffiliated entity. The term "controlling
interest", as used herein, means majority equity ownership of a grantee.
   C.   In the case of any sale or transfer of ownership of an interest in or
control of a franchise or cable system, the village shall have one hundred
twenty (120) days to act upon any request for approval of such sale or transfer
that contains or is accompanied by such information as is required in
accordance with FCC regulations and the requirements of this title and the
applicable franchise agreement. If the village fails to render a final decision
on the request within the statutory one hundred twenty (120) day time period,
such request shall be deemed granted unless the requesting party and the
village agree to an extension of the one hundred twenty (120) day period.
   D.   The grantor reserves any rights it may have to require that a grantee
pay all reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the grantor in connection
with the sale, assignment, or transfer of a franchise, including, but not
limited to, the grantor's reasonable costs of reviewing the qualifications of
any proposed transferees. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
CHAPTER 12
RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUALS PROTECTED
SECTION:
13-12-1: Discriminatory Practices Prohibited
13-12-2: Subscriber Privacy
13-12-1: DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES PROHIBITED:
No grantee shall deny service, deny access, or otherwise discriminate against
subscribers, programmers, or general citizens on the basis of race, color,
religion, national origin, sex, disability, or age. Every grantee shall
strictly adhere to the equal employment opportunity requirements of state and
federal law. Each grantee shall comply at all times with all other applicable
federal, state, and local laws, and all executive and administrative orders
relating to nondiscrimination. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
13-12-2: SUBSCRIBER PRIVACY:
Grantees shall at all times comply with the federal subscriber privacy
requirements codified at 47 USC section 551. (Ord. 1241, 6-18-2001)
